A. Laboratories, Shops/Facilities
fields.description: In general, facilities include well-equipped rooms which are adequately ventilated/air-conditioned, and lighted. The furniture are properly arranged. Safety devices and measures to cope with emergency situations are available. Facilities conform with accepted standards.

fields.name: B. Equipment and Supplies
fields.description: Certain courses require specific equipment, materials and supplies. The list of these equipment, materials and supplies should be included under the section on special provisions for the academic program. Apparatuses, tools and materials conform to specifications as required.

fields.name: C. Maintenance
fields.description: All laboratory equipment should be stored properly, maintained, and checked regularly to ascertain their good working condition.

fields.name: D. Special Provisions
fields.description: The special provisions should include the program requirements (listing of materials and equipment as per CMO). There should be an approved Annual Procurement Plan (APP).

fields.name: A. ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The library should be administered and supervised by a full-time, professional librarian with at least, a Master�s degree in Library and Information Science under a functional organizational set-up. It should be administered in a manner which allows and encourages the fullest and most effective use of available library resources.

fields.name: B. ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF
fields.description: The library should have a sufficient staff of staff to organize and maintain the collection as well as to manage information and reference services for the clientele.

fields.name: C. COLLECTION DEVELOPMENT, ORGANIZATION AND PRESERVATION
fields.description: The library�s varied resources should be adequate to serve the institution�s instructional and research needs. It must have a system of progressive development and growth in accordance with the Institutional Development Plan.

fields.name: D. SERVICES AND UTILIZATION
fields.description: The overriding goal of the library is to provide services to the academic community. These services are measured by their effectiveness in meeting the user�s needs.

fields.name: E. PHYSICAL SET-UP AND FACILITIES
fields.description: The library should provide adequate and appropriate space and facilities to serve the academic community. It should be strategically planned and functionally designed to allow for rearrangement and future expansion. A separate building for the library would be ideal.

fields.name: F. FINANCIAL SUPPORT
fields.description: The library should have a separate, realistic and adequate budget to support its various activities and services. The budget proposal is prepared in consultation with the Library Board/Committee.

fields.name: G. LINKAGES
fields.description: A network of alliances/relationships extending beyond the Institution could enhance the library services. These linkages may be customary, contractual or cooperative. In collaboration with other libraries, it participates in activities that could enhance the attainment of its objectives.

fields.name: A. CAMPUS
fields.description: The site should be located a wholesome environment, safe from traffic and transportation hazards, sufficiently free from noise, dust, smoke, and other undesirable elements. It should be provided with adequate facilities for drainage and sewage disposal. It should be adequate to meet the needs of the present school population and its future expansion. The school should be accessible to present and anticipated school population by means of public and private transportation. It should have satisfactory road network and sidewalks.

fields.name: B. BUILDINGS
fields.description: The buildings should be functionally designed and constructed of strong and durable materials to withstand natural calamities like earthquakes, typhoons, and fire. Their design should be pleasing to the eye and in conformity with the surroundings. At the same time, these are imbued with the proper atmosphere conducive to learning. Likewise, there should be provisions for disabled persons.

fields.name: C. CLASSROOMS
fields.description: The size and number of classrooms should be in accordance with the standards and sufficient to accommodate the student population. Classrooms should be adequately equipped with the required furniture, blackboards/whiteboards, and should have a pleasant atmosphere. Lighting, ventilation, general appearance, and acoustics should be satisfactory.

fields.name: D. OFFICES, STAFF AND FUNCTION ROOMS
fields.description: Adequate provisions should be made for administrative offices, faculty rooms, and reception areas, where needed.

fields.name: E. ASSEMBLY AND ATHLETIC FACILITIES
fields.description: Group assembly facilities should have a seating capacity adequate to meet the needs of the Institution. These facilities should be designed with good acoustics and proper ventilation. Necessary facilities and equipment should be adequate and kept in good condition. Athletic facilities should be accessible to the students, and must be sufficient in number and variety, depending on the requirements of the school population. There should be suitable arrangements for athletic activities during the rainy season.

fields.name: F. MEDICAL AND DENTAL CLINIC
fields.description: A medical and dental clinic should be properly set-up strategically located, well-ventilated and lighted, screened, and provided with clean water supply. It should be spacious enough to accommodate the five (5) distinct sections: 1) reception area; 2) examination room; 3) treatment room; 4) dental section; and 5) rest/recovery room, separate for male and female. It should be provided with basic equipment, medical supplies, beds, cabinets, and linen.

fields.name: G. STUDENT CENTER
fields.description: A Student Center is available where students can make wholesome interaction and listen to good music, play table games, watch TV programs, etc.

fields.name: H. FOOD SERVICES/CANTEEN
fields.description: Clean and sanitary food services unit/canteen must be set up and managed effectively. It should serve balanced yet affordable meals and snacks to the school community.

fields.name: I. ACCREDITATION CENTER
fields.description: There should be a properly maintained and equipped Accreditation Center with necessary facilities.

fields.name: J. HOUSING
fields.description: Housing should be maintained and provided with electricity and water. This should have proper drainage and waste disposal system.

fields.name: A. STATEMENT OF VISION, MISSION, GOALS AND OBJECTIVES
fields.description: The Vision in the state the Institution hopes to become in the future. The MGO represents the hierarchy of aims of the Institution. The Mission reflects the mandate/aim of the whole state university or state college. The Goals are the aims at the hierarchical structure below the Institutional level (the academic Unit/Institute/School); and the Objectives are the aims at the program level, i. e., what the program hopes to achieve.

fields.name: B. DISSEMINATION AND ACCEPTABILITY
fields.description: It is expected that the institution disseminates, and work for the acceptance of the Vision, Mission, Goals and Objectives by the stakeholders. In order to facilitate awareness and acceptance, it is a good practice that the faculty, non-teaching staff, students, linkages, the community, and other stakeholders are involved in the formulation, review and/or revision of the VMGO.

fields.name: A. ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS AND PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE
fields.description: The faculty should have the appropriate academic preparation and experience relevant to the program. They must be holders of appropriate degrees. In case of any deficiency, they should possess relevant and/or compensatory qualifications. Moreover, they must be licensed (where applicable) if they are handling  professional subjects. They must exhibit competence as evidenced by their professional license, performance evaluation, consultancy and scholarly works.

fields.name: B. RECRUITMENT, SELECTION AND ORIENTATION
fields.description: Recruitment and selection of the faculty are among the important activities undertaken by an institution. Success in the implementation of an academic program depends to a grate extent on the quality of the faculty.

fields.name: C. FACULTY ADEQUACY AND LOADING
fields.description: The Institution should have an adequate number of faculty with the appropriate qualifications to handle the courses offered by a particular program. Teaching assignment/loading should be based on the major/minor fields of specialization of the faculty. Their workload should allow them time to prepare lessons, score papers and other course requirements, advise students, conduct research and extension activities and perform other instruction-related activities and institutional service. If possible, the faculty should not be given more than three academic subject preparations.

fields.name: D. RANK AND TENURE
fields.description: The Institution should implement a system of promotion in rank and salary based on existing policies and guidelines. Faculty members must be informed of the Institutional policies on probation, extension, renewal or termination of contract, promotion, and retirement.

fields.name: E. FACULTY DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: The Institution should have a well-funded Faculty Development Program. The program should include criteria for the selection of scholars/grantees, and opportunities/study privileges, research grants, training, etc. that are available. Faculty members should be encouraged to join professional organizations and to continuously upgrade their knowledge and competence by participating in in-service training activities such as seminars, conferences, workshops, etc.

fields.name: F. PERFORMANCE AND SCHOLARLY WORKS
fields.description: Teaching is the main function of the faculty and a performance evaluation system should be based on objective criteria. The faculty should also be involved in the dissemination of knowledge, innovations, and technologies in national and international fora and in the development of instructional materials such as modules, software, teach wares, multi-media devices, etc. Moreover, they are expected to render exert services and consultancies.

fields.name: G. SALARIES, FRINGE BENEFITS AND INCENTIVES
fields.description: The salary scale of the faculty follows the DBM Salary Standardization Scheme and the most recent government issuances on compensation. Fringe benefits of faculty members such as leave privileges and financial assistance should be embodied in the Institution�s Code or Manual in consonance with CSC and other government policies and guidelines. Overloads are appropriately compensated. Outstanding performance (publication, reproduction, scholarly works, etc.) of faculty should be recognized and incentives be given correspondingly.

fields.name: H. PROFESSIONALISM
fields.description: Professionalism should be practiced based on the SUC Code, the Civil Service Code of Ethical Standards for Government Officials and Employees (RA 6713), and the Code of Ethics for the Profession. Academic freedom should be judiciously exercised

fields.name: A. PRIORITIES AND RELEVANCE
fields.description: The Institution shall conceptualize and implement identified researches (preferably multidisciplinary and collaborative in nature) in consonance with institutional, regional and national priorities. The Institution�s research should be consistent with its priorities and those emphasized in the Agenda of the DOST, CHED, NEDA, etc.

fields.name: B. FUNDING AND OTHER RESOURCES
fields.description: The Institution shall be encouraged to allocate funds for research regularly. Resources from various local and foreign agencies should be explored to augment the Institution�s appropriation. In-house reviews shall be conducted periodically. Research results are disseminated to local and national instrumentalities interested in collaborating with academic institutions.

fields.name: C. IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING, EVALUATION AND UTILIZATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS/OUTPUTS
fields.description: The faculty are required to undertake or conduct research especially in their fields of specialization to supplement and improve the teaching-learning process and satisfy one of the four-fold mandated functions of the Institution. To sustain the quality of researches, Incentives through honoraria, grant of service credits, and work-load adjustments shall be accorded to the faculty who are conducting researches and publishing their outputs. Likewise, continues upgrading of faculty and research staff is undertaken by the institution to enhance research capabilities and competence. The conduct of department researches shall be encouraged in addition to specialized researches undertaken by the faculty. At best, a collective and/or collaborative research undertaken by the Institution/Academic Unit must be defined and focused. Moreover, completed researches shall be pilot-tested and eventually utilized.

fields.name: D. PUBLICATION AND DISSEMINATION
fields.description: Researches whether on the proposal, on-going or completed stage may be published in the proper media and well disseminated to target clientele. The institution implements incentives schemes for publication and paper presentation of research outputs in national and international fora.

fields.name: A. PRIORITIES AND RELEVANCE
fields.description: Extension services are provided by the Academic Unit in response to the needs and urgent concerns of the community it serves. Likewise, it takes into consideration local, regional and national development thrusts. The services extended should be reflective of the Institution�s vision, mission, goals and objectives.

fields.name: B. PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING AND EVALUATION
fields.description: There is an extension unit which coordinates a functional extension program. Stakeholders, administration, faculty, and students are involved in the planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of extension activities. Multi-disciplinary or multi-sectorial approach is encouraged in the conduct of the various extension activities, including the assessment of the impact of each extension activity implemented for various clientele.

fields.name: C. FUNDING AND OTHER RESOURCES
fields.description: The extension program is provided regularly with a definite budget to ensure its sustainability. Funds, as well as material and service inputs from the Institution or from other agencies, are needed in the implementation of a viable extension program.

fields.name: D. COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT AND PARTICIPATION
fields.description: A harmonious and collaborative school-community relationship is a major factor in the life of an extension program. The community should be invited to participate in the planning, implementing, monitoring and evaluation of activities, as well as sourcing of funds and other resources.

fields.name: A. CURRICULUM AND PROGRAM OF STUDIES
fields.description: The Curriculum must have content and design that will enable the students to achieve intended learning outcomes. It should work towards the attainment of the mission of the Institution, and the attainment of the course objectives. It should include recent developments in teaching and learning techniques, and other attributes necessary for employment, such as teamwork, communication, leadership skills, etc.

fields.name: B. INSTRUCTIONAL PROCESSES, METHODOLOGIES AND LEARNING ENHANCEMENT OPPORTUNITIES
fields.description: The instructional process should provide learning opportunities for the students. It should also make use of different strategies, methodologies and techniques. Learning opportunities could be in the following areas: 1) teaching and learning 2) professional development; and 3) collaboration.

fields.name: C. ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE
fields.description: Assessment is an integral part of a curricular program for purposes of continuous improvement. It is used to demonstrate how well the program carries out the mission of Institution. The methods used for assessment should demonstrate reliable relationships between the educational experiences (curriculum) and the expected /outcomes. Assessment may be done before, during, and after the implementation of the curricular program.

fields.name: D. MANAGEMENT OF LEARNING
fields.description: The rules and practices relating to classroom management should be conductive to effective instruction should be carefully observed. Measures should be taken to ensure punctual attendance of faculty members in their scheduled classes. The rule on absences should follow the institution�s policy. Records of these absences should be kept.

fields.name: E. GRADUATION REQUIREMENTS
fields.description: Requirements for graduation are made clear and well-known to the students. Research, practicum, on-the-job training and other activities prescribed in the curriculum as requirements for graduation should be strictly implemented to further improve quality of graduates.

fields.name: F. ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FOR EFFFECTIVE INSTRUCTION
fields.description: Quality instruction should be sustain by providing the required instructional materials like syllabi, assessment instruments, etc., to make teaching learning meaningful and fruitful. To ensure effective instruction, it is necessary that students and faculty are punctual in their respective classes. Likewise, this is sustained through utilization of updated/enhanced instructional materials like syllabi, examination questions and departmental examinations; provisions for substitutions and special arrangements for absences or leaves of faculty members; and supervisory visits to monitor academic activities.

fields.name: A. ORGANIZATION
fields.description: An educational institution should have a Governing Board of Regents/Trustees. This Board has the responsibility to formulate general policies. The policies should be implemented by a sufficient number of qualified officials duly appointed/designated for the purpose. A detailed description of the organizational set-up of the whole Institution under survey should be found in an official document.

fields.name: B. ACADEMIC ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The area covers administrative and academic matters such as qualification of academic officials; recruitment and promotion of faculty and support staff; setting standards and targets; planning, implementing and monitoring of programs and other related activities; establishing linkages, partnerships and networking activities; professional growth development opportunities; proper use and maintenance of facilities, equipment, etc.; and generating resources and income and cost effective measures.

fields.name: C. STUDENT ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The following activities fall under this Area: admission and retention policies; registration, school fees, academic load, transfers, residence, course work, scholastic and graduation requirements, examination and grading system, scholarship/grants, shifting and adding/dropping of course, code of conduct and discipline, availability of a student handbook, and organization of the recorded data for statistical use.

fields.name: D. FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT
fields.description: The business administration of the Institution should be well-maintained and managed by qualified and competent personnel. Business function are well-delineated to promote fiscal integrity, economy, responsibility and accountability.

fields.name: E. SUPPLY MANAGEMENT
fields.description: Supplies support the operations of the Institution. The Institution therefore should have a scheme of managing supplies, materials and equipment. While committees may assist the Institution in the procurement of these supplies/materials/equipment, a supply management office takes charge of their procurement distribution and storage.

fields.name: F. RECORDS MANAGEMENT
fields.description: Records and reports include: minutes of the board meetings, minutes of faculty meetings, faculty directory; records of faculty training and experience; records of enrollment by class, gender and course; students� directory; alumni directory; recorded data for statistical use; inventory of property; reports of administrative officials; summary of disciplinary matters; records of scholarships granted, etc. Adequate, accurate, accessible, up-to-date and systematic records are indicators of sound records management.

fields.name: G. INSTITUTINAL PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: Sound Institutional planning should show concern for, and attention to, the following: congruence with the institutional vision and mission, academic unit�s goals and program objectives; alignment with national, regional, and local goals and needs; adequate allocation of resources; participation of all sectors of the academic community in the planning process; formal documentation of all plans and progress of implementation; long- and short-term dimensions of planning; and mechanisms for periodic review, evaluation and updating. A Planning Officer should be responsible for the coordination of the planning activity.

fields.name: H. PERFORMANCE OF ADMINISTRATIVE PERSONNEL
fields.description: The administrative personnel should be qualified to perform the various administrative services. The performance evaluation of the personnel should include: (1) competence; (2) quality of work; (3) work ethic; (4) creative ability; (5) interpersonal relations; and (6) ability to handle internal and external pressures.

fields.name: A. STUDENT SERVICES PROGRAM (SSP)
fields.description: There should be a well-organized, properly administered and adequately staffed Student Services Program (SSP). Such a program should be provided with adequate services, physical facilities and adequate resources to attain its objectives. A program of activities and services such as Student Welfare, Student Development, Institutional Student Programs and Services should be known and accepted by the administrators, faculty and students.

fields.name: B. STUDENT WELFARE
fields.description: The Student Welfare Services are basic services and programs needed to ensure and promote the well-being of students. These include Information, Orientation and Awareness, Guidance and Counseling, Career and Placement, Economic enterprise Development, and Student Handbook Development.

fields.name: C. STUDENT DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: Student Development is composed of programs and activities designed for the enhancement and deepening of leadership skills and social responsibility. This includes student organizations and activities, professional organization or societies, special interests, Leadership Training Programs, Student Council/Government, Student Discipline, Student publication/Media.

fields.name: D. INSTITUTIONAL STUDENT PROGRAMS AND SERVICES
fields.description: These are programs and activities that would facilitate the delivery of essential services to the students such as: a) Admission; b) Scholarship and Financial Assistance; c) Food; d) Health; e) Security and Safety; f) Housing and Residential Services; g) Multi-Faith; h) Foreign Students; i) services for Students with Special Needs; j) culture and arts; k) sports; l) social; and m) community involvement.

fields.name: E. RESEAARCH, MONITORING AND EVALUATION
fields.description: The Institution should encourage the students to conduct research on student affairs and services programs. The results should be disseminated and utilized, monitoring and evaluation of student affairs and services can serve as feedback mechanism to ensure sustainability and effectiveness of the Student Affairs and Services program.

fields.name: 1. AREA I - VISION, MISSION, GOALS and OBJECTIVES
A. STATEMENT OF VISION, MISSION, GOALS AND OBJECTIVES
fields.description: The Vision in the state the Institution hopes to become in the future. The MGO represents the hierarchy of aims of the Institution. The Mission reflects the mandate/aim of the whole state university or state college. The Goals are the aims at the hierarchical structure below the Institutional level (the academic Unit/Institute/School); and the Objectives are the aims at the program level, i. e., what the program hopes to achieve.

fields.name: B. DISSEMINATION AND ACCEPTABILITY
fields.description: It is expected that the institution disseminates, and work for the acceptance of the Vision, Mission, Goals and Objectives by the stakeholders. In order to facilitate awareness and acceptance, it is a good practice that the faculty, non-teaching staff, students, linkages, the community, and other stakeholders are involved in the formulation, review and/or revision of the VMGO.

fields.name: A. ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS AND PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE
fields.description: The faculty should have the appropriate academic preparation and experience relevant to the program. They must be holders of appropriate degrees. In case of any deficiency, they should possess relevant and/or compensatory qualifications. Moreover, they must be licensed (where applicable) if they are handling  professional subjects. They must exhibit competence as evidenced by their professional license, performance evaluation, consultancy and scholarly works.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The required number of faculty possess graduate degrees appropriate and relevant to the Graduate education program, namely:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: For a Master degree program in Teacher Education at least 5 full-time faculty members who have published works in professional journals;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: Of the five, at least two (2) have doctoral degree holder;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: At least three (3) of the five full-time faculty members have advanced training in the major area being offered;

fields.name: S.1.4.
fields.description: Of the three, at least one has doctoral degree in the major area being offered.

fields.name: S.1.5.
fields.description: For doctoral program there must be at least five (5) faculty who are doctoral degree holders and who have published works in refereed professional journals; and

fields.name: S.1.6.
fields.description: At least three (3) of the five have advanced training in the major area being offered.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: Other qualification such as the following are considered:

fields.name: S.2.1.
fields.description: related professional experience;

fields.name: S.2.2.
fields.description: technical skills and competence; and

fields.name: S.2.3.
fields.description: special abilities, computer literacy, research productivity.

fields.description: production;

fields.name: I.1.5.
fields.description: consultancy and expert service; and

fields.name: I.1.6.
fields.description: publication, creative and scholarly work.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The institution has qualified and competent faculty.

fields.name: B. RECRUITMENT, SELECTION AND ORIENTATION
fields.description: Recruitment and selection of the faculty are among the important activities undertaken by an institution. Success in the implementation of an academic program depends to a grate extent on the quality of the faculty.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: There is an institutional Human Resource Development Plan/Program designed for faculty recruitment.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description:
Recruitment and selection of faculty is processed by the Faculty Selection Board using the following  criteria:

Mandatory

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: academic qualifications;

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: personal qualities;

fields.name: I.1.3.
fields.description: communication skills;

fields.name: I.1.4.
fields.description: teaching ability;

fields.name: I.1.5.
fields.description: medical examination results;

fields.name: I.1.6.
fields.description: psychological examination results;

fields.name: I.1.7.
fields.description: relevant professional experiences (if any);

fields.name: I.1.8.
fields.description: previous record of employment (if any);

fields.name: I.1.9.
fields.description: technical/special skills & abilities; and

fields.name: I.1.10.
fields.description: previous performance rating (if any).

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The hiring system adopts an open competitive selection, based on the CSC-approved Merit System and Promotion Plan of the institution published and well-disseminated through various means of communication:

fields.name: I.2.1.
fields.description: print media (newspaper, flyers, CSC Bulletin of Vacant Positions);

fields.name: I.2.2.
fields.description: broadcast media (TV, radio);

fields.name: I.2.3.
fields.description: website; and

fields.name: I.2.4.
fields.description: bulletin boards;

fields.name: I.2.5.
fields.description: others (please specify) _________.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: A Screening Committee selects and recommends the best and most qualified applicant.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: Measures to avoid professional in-breeding are observed.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The institution conducts orientation for the newly-hired faculty on its institutional vision and mission, CSC, PRC, DBM, and administration policies on their duties and responsibilities, benefits and other academic concerns.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The most qualified faculty are selected.

fields.name: C. FACULTY ADEQUACY AND LOADING
fields.description: The Institution should have an adequate number of faculty with the appropriate qualifications to handle the courses offered by a particular program. Teaching assignment/loading should be based on the major/minor fields of specialization of the faculty. Their workload should allow them time to prepare lessons, score papers and other course requirements, advise students, conduct research and extension activities and perform other instruction-related activities and institutional service. If possible, the faculty should not be given more than three academic subject preparations.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: Faculty-student ratio is in accordance with the program requirements and standards as follows:

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a provision for incentives of overload teaching in accordance with the CMO of the program and/or institutional guidelines.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The faculty members are assigned to courses where they have the most expertise and training.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: Faculty schedule has time for preparation of lessons, scoring of test papers, record-keeping, class evaluation and other instruction-related activities.

fields.name: S.5.
fields.description: Workload Guidelines contain sufficient time for teaching and/or research, extension, production and other assigned tasks.

fields.name: S.6.
fields.description: There is equitable, measurable and fair distribution of teaching load and other assignments.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The maximum total load of a regular full-time faculty member in the graduate level is six (6) units per term. The load including other assignments at the undergraduate level is based on the CMO and/or institutional guidelines.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: A Faculty Manual is published formalizing faculty policies standards and guidelines.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: Professional subjects are handled by specialists in the discipline.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The faculty members are assigned to teach their major/minor fields of specialization for a maximum of four (4) different subject preparations within a semester.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: Administrative arrangements are adopted whenever vacancies/leaves of absence occur during the term.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: Administrative, research or professional assignment outside of regular teaching is given credits.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: Consultation, tutorial, remedial classes, expert services and other instruction-related activities are given credits.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The faculty are efficient and effective with sufficient time for instruction, research, extension, production and other assigned tasks.

fields.name: D. RANK AND TENURE
fields.description: The Institution should implement a system of promotion in rank and salary based on existing policies and guidelines. Faculty members must be informed of the Institutional policies on probation, extension, renewal or termination of contract, promotion, and retirement.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The institution has a system of promotion in rank and tenure based on official issuances.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The institution has a policy on probationary status of employment.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The institution implements the system of promotion in rank and salary based on existing policies and issuances (e.g. NBC 461).

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: Retirement, separation or termination benefits are implemented in accordance with institutional and government (CSC, GSIS/DBM) policies and guidelines.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The faculty are official informed of their rank and tenure after evaluation of their credentials and performance.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The faculty concerned is officially informed of the extension, renewal, or termination of their appointments.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The institution implements a CSC-approved Strategic Performance Management System (SPMS) which emphasizes quality teaching performance, research, creative work, extension and production services.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The faculty are satisfied with their rank and employment status.

fields.name: E. FACULTY DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: The Institution should have a well-funded Faculty Development Program. The program should include criteria for the selection of scholars/grantees, and opportunities/study privileges, research grants, training, etc. that are available. Faculty members should be encouraged to join professional organizations and to continuously upgrade their knowledge and competence by participating in in-service training activities such as seminars, conferences, workshops, etc.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The institution has an approved and sustainable Faculty Development Program (FDP).

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There are policies on faculty academic recognition and grant of scholarships/fellowships, and awards.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: Every faculty member has at least one active membership in professional/scientific organizations or honor society relevant to his/her assignment and field of specialization.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: The budget allocation for faculty development is adequate.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The institution implements a sustainable Faculty Development Program (FDP) based on identified priorities/needs such as:

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: upgraded educational qualifications

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: attendance to seminars, symposia and conferences

fields.name: I.1.3.
fields.description: conduct of research activities and publication of research outputs; and

fields.name: I.1.4.
fields.description: giving lectures and presentation of papers in national, international conferences, symposia and seminars.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The institution supports the professional growth of the faculty through attendance in educational lectures, symposia, seminars, workshops, conferences and other forms of training.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The institution conducts in-service training activities regularly at least once per term.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: Selection of deserving faculty members to be granted scholarships, fellowships, seminars, conferences and/or training grants is done objectively.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The budget for faculty development is adequately allocated.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: The budget for faculty development is wisely utilized.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: The Faculty Development Program is implemented with the following provisions:

fields.name: I.7.1.
fields.description: adequate and qualified supervision of faculty;

fields.name: I.7.2.
fields.description: scholarships, fellowships, sabbatical leaves, and research/travel grants;

fields.name: I.7.3.
fields.description: financial support for active membership in professional organizations;

fields.name: I.7.4.
fields.description: deloading to finish the faculty�s thesis/dissertation;

fields.name: I.7.5.
fields.description: attendance in continuing professional education (CPE) programs such as seminars, workshops, conferences, or some in service training courses.

fields.name: I.7.6.
fields.description: conducting research related to the program;

fields.name: I.7.7.
fields.description: publishing scholarly articles and research outputs; and

fields.name: I.7.8.
fields.description: production of instructional materials.

fields.name: I.8.
fields.description: Opportunities for the faculty to attend capability building and enhancing activities are fairly distributed.

fields.name: I.9.
fields.description: Tuition fee privilege and other forms of assistance are utilized for faculty pursuing advanced (master�s and/or doctoral) degrees.

fields.name: I.10.
fields.description: Faculty members are given incentives for book writing, manuals, handbooks, compilations and instructional materials and keep up with new knowledge and techniques in the field of specialization.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The faculty are well-trained and competent to serve the institution.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: The faculty are committed to serve and support the programs and projects of the institution.

fields.name: F. PERFORMANCE AND SCHOLARLY WORKS
fields.description: Teaching is the main function of the faculty and a performance evaluation system should be based on objective criteria. The faculty should also be involved in the dissemination of knowledge, innovations, and technologies in national and international fora and in the development of instructional materials such as modules, software, teach wares, multi-media devices, etc. Moreover, they are expected to render exert services and consultancies.

fields.name: 1. SYSTEM � INPUTS AND PROCESSES
fields.description: The Faculty

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The institution has a system of evaluating the faculty on the following;

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: professional performance; and

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: scholarly works.

fields.name: 2. IMPLEMENTATION
fields.description: The Faculty

fields.name: I.1
fields.description: demonstrate skills and competencies in all of the following:

fields.name: I.1.1.

fields.name: I.1.2.

fields.name: I.1.3.
fields.description: knowledge and mastery of the content, issues and methodologies in the discipline;

fields.name: I.1.4.
fields.description: proficiency in the use of the language of instruction;

fields.name: I.1.5.
fields.description: the use of higher-order thinking skills such as analytical, critical, creative, innovative and problem solving;

fields.name: I.1.6.
fields.description: innovativeness and resourcefulness in the different instructional processes; and

fields.name: I.1.7.
fields.description: integration of values and work ethics in the teaching-learning process; and

fields.name: I.1.8.
fields.description: integration of Gender and Development (GAD) activities

fields.description: promptly submit required reports and other academic outputs.

fields.name: I.3.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: serve as resource person/lecturer/consultant in the field.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: present papers in local/regional/national and/or international fora.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: publish papers in regional, national and international magazines/journals.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: conduct research and publish outputs in refereed journals of national and international circulation.

fields.name: I.8.
fields.description: conduct extension and outreach activities.

fields.name: I.9.
fields.description: regularly updates respective course syllabi.

fields.name: I.10.
fields.description: utilize ICT and other resources in the enhancement of the teaching-learning process.

fields.name: I.11.
fields.description: produce instructional materials, e.g. workbooks, manuals, modules, audio-visual aids, etc. to facilitate teaching and learning.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The faculty performances are generally satisfactory.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: The scholarly works of the faculty are commendable.

fields.name: G. SALARIES, FRINGE BENEFITS AND INCENTIVES
fields.description: The salary scale of the faculty follows the DBM Salary Standardization Scheme and the most recent government issuances on compensation. Fringe benefits of faculty members such as leave privileges and financial assistance should be embodied in the Institution�s Code or Manual in consonance with CSC and other government policies and guidelines. Overloads are appropriately compensated. Outstanding performance (publication, reproduction, scholarly works, etc.) of faculty should be recognized and incentives be given correspondingly.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The institution has a system of compensation and rewards to its faculty and staff.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The following fringe benefits are granted:

fields.name: I.1.1.

fields.name: I.1.2.

fields.name: I.1.3.

fields.name: I.1.4.
fields.description: vacation leave;

fields.description: tuition fee discount for faculty and their dependents;

fields.name: I.1.6.

fields.name: I.1.7.
fields.description: performance based bonus (PBB);

fields.name: I.1.8.

fields.name: I.1.9.

fields.name: I.3.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: Teaching assignments beyond the regular load are compensated (e.g., overload pay, service credits, etc.)

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: Faculty with outstanding performance are given recognition/awards and incentives.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The faculty are satisfied with their compensation and rewards.

fields.name: H. PROFESSIONALISM
fields.description: Professionalism should be practiced based on the SUC Code, the Civil Service Code of Ethical Standards for Government Officials and Employees (RA 6713), and the Code of Ethics for the Profession. Academic freedom should be judiciously exercised

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: There are approved SUC Code and SUC Faculty Manual that define the policies, guidelines, rules and regulations affecting the faculty.

fields.name: 2. IMPLEMENTATION

fields.name: I.1.4.

fields.name: I.1.5.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: follow the Code of Ethics of the Profession and the Code of Ethical Standards for Government Officials and Employees (RA 6713).

fields.name: I.4.3.

fields.name: I.4.4.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: maintain harmonious interpersonal relations with superiors, peers, students, parents and the community.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: demonstrate knowledge of recent educational trends/issues/resources in the field of Graduate Education.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: show evidence of professional growth through further and continuing studies.

fields.name: I.8.
fields.description: engage in practices which enable the faculty to demonstrate harmonious interpersonal relations with the students, parents and the community.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The corps of faculty manifests a commendable level of professionalism.

fields.name: A. CURRICULUM AND PROGRAM OF STUDIES
fields.description: The Curriculum must have content and design that will enable the students to achieve intended learning outcomes. It should work towards the attainment of the mission of the Institution, and the attainment of the course objectives. It should include recent developments in teaching and learning techniques, and other attributes necessary for employment, such as teamwork, communication, leadership skills, etc.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: Graduate education being the apex of the educational system, its curriculum showcases the best of the academic and intellectual products and processes of the system through the development of the following competencies:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: acquisition of advanced knowledge and theories based on the field of specialization;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: application of theories to actual problems in the field; and

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: demonstrating enhanced skills to carry out the application or strategy in actual complex work settings

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a system of validation of subjects taken from other schools.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The curriculum reflects the local, regional, and national development goals as well as institution�s vision and mission.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The curriculum/program of study meets the requirements and standards of CHED as follows:

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: Master�s thesis program � 36 units inclusive of (6) units thesis;

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: Master�s non-thesis program inclusive of six (6) integrating courses � 36 units

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The curricular content is responsive to the needs of the country and recent developments in the profession.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The curricular content covers the extent of the professional and technical preparation required of its graduates.

fields.name: I.4.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: Opportunities for participation in hands-on activities, such as immersion/practical training and field study are maintained in the curriculum.

fields.description: participative planning and designing of the curriculum by the following stakeholders:

fields.name: I.6.1.1.
fields.description: administration;

fields.name: I.6.1.2.

fields.name: I.6.1.3.
fields.description: students;

fields.name: I.6.1.4.
fields.description: alumni;

fields.name: I.7.

fields.description: The curriculum is responsive and relevant to the demand of times.

fields.name: B. INSTRUCTIONAL PROCESSES, METHODOLOGIES AND LEARNING ENHANCEMENT OPPORTUNITIES
fields.description: The instructional process should provide learning opportunities for the students. It should also make use of different strategies, methodologies and techniques. Learning opportunities could be in the following areas: 1) teaching and learning 2) professional development; and 3) collaboration.

fields.name: S.2.

fields.name: C. ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE
fields.description: Assessment is an integral part of a curricular program for purposes of continuous improvement. It is used to demonstrate how well the program carries out the mission of Institution. The methods used for assessment should demonstrate reliable relationships between the educational experiences (curriculum) and the expected /outcomes. Assessment may be done before, during, and after the implementation of the curricular program.

To sustain the quality of researches, Incentives through honoraria, grant of service credits, and work-load adjustments shall be accorded to the faculty who are conducting researches and publishing their outputs. Likewise, continues upgrading of faculty and research staff is undertaken by the institution to enhance research capabilities and competence. The conduct of department researches shall be encouraged in addition to specialized researches undertaken by the faculty. At best, a collective and/or collaborative research undertaken by the Institution/Academic Unit must be defined and focused. Moreover, completed researches shall be pilot-tested and eventually utilized.

fields.name: 8. AREA VIII - PHYSICAL PLANT and FACILITIES
A. CAMPUS
fields.description: The site should be located a wholesome environment, safe from traffic and transportation hazards, sufficiently free from noise, dust, smoke, and other undesirable elements. It should be provided with adequate facilities for drainage and sewage disposal. It should be adequate to meet the needs of the present school population and its future expansion. The school should be accessible to present and anticipated school population by means of public and private transportation. It should have satisfactory road network and sidewalks.

fields.name: AREA I: VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES
fields.description: The area of Vision, Mission, Goals, and Objectives is the most fundamental of all the ten (10) areas to be surveyed. Everything in the Institution is justified only to the extent that it realizes its vision and mission. It is essential therefore for the Institution to formulate the vision and mission which should be the bases of all its operations. The Institution should be judged by the degree to which these are attained, not in comparison with the others.

fields.name: 6.1 Actions to Address Risks and Opportunities
PARAMETER A: STATEMENT OF VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES
fields.description:
The Vision is the state the Institution hopes to become in the future. The MGO represents the hierarchy of aims of the institution. The Mission reflects the mandate /aim of the whole state university or state college. The Goals are the aims at the hierarchical structure below the institutional level  (the academic Unit/Institute/School); and the Objectives are the aims at the program level, i.e., what the program hopes to achieve.

The Institution shall define its mission in accordance with its legal and educational development mandate and the thrusts of the government.

The program outcomes are the foci of program accreditation. These are the competencies (knowledge and skills), values, and other attributes, which the Institution hopes their graduates shall acquire to enable them to compete for employment, locally and internationally.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has a system of determining its vision and mission.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Vision clearly reflects what the the Institution hopes to become in the future.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The Mission clearly reflects the Institution's legal and other statutory mandate.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: The Goals of the College/Academic Unit are consistent with the Mission of the Institution.

fields.name: 6.2 Quality Objectives and Planning to Achieve them
8.3 Design and development of products and services

fields.description: The Objectives of the program have the expected outcomes in terms of competencies (skills and knowledge) values, and other attributes of the graduates, which include the development of:

fields.name: S.5.1.
fields.description: technical skills in Graduate education;

fields.name: S.5.2.

fields.name: S.5.3.

fields.name: S.5.4.
fields.description: moral character;

fields.name: S.5.5.
fields.description: critical, analytical, problem solving and other higher order thinking skills, and;

fields.name: S.5.6.
fields.description: aesthetic and cultural values.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution/Academic Unit conducts a review on the statement of the Vision and Mission as well as its goals and program objectives for the approval of authorities concerned.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The College/Academic Unit follows a system of formulating its goals and the objectives of the program.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The College's/Academic Unit's faculty, personnel, students, and other stakeholders (cooperating agencies, linkages, alumni, industry sector, and other concerned groups) participate in the formulation , review and/or revision of the VMGO.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: DISSEMINATION AND ACCEPTABILITY
fields.description:
It is expected that the Institution disseminates, and works for the acceptance of the Vision, Mission, Goals, and Objectives  by the stakeholders. In order to facilitate awareness and acceptance, it is a good practice that the faculty, non-teaching staff, students, linkages, the community, and other stakeholders are involved in the formulation, review and/or revision of the VMGO.

An outcomes-based assessment will focus on the extent to which the program objectives are attained as shown in the outcomes. Thus, there must be a common understanding and acceptance of the end results of the program by both the faculty and the students.

It should be demonstrated that the program objectives (outcomes) are consistent with the College goals; and the College goals with the Mission of the University. On a long-term perspective, the accomplishment of the Mission will lead to the realization of the Vision of the Institution.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The VMGO are available on bulletin boards, in catalogs/manuals, and in other forms of communication media.

fields.name: AREA II: FACULTY
fields.description:
The standard or quality of an Institution or Program is greatly measured by the qualifications of its faculty. In this light, the faculty should be composed of competent members in terms of academic qualifications, experience, and professional expertise. In addition, they should manifest desirable personal qualities and high level of professionalism.

To be effective, faculty members should be properly compensated and taken care of. They must be given opportunities for continuous personal and professional development. A policy of fair and equitable distribution of teaching assignments and workload should be practiced. Likewise, objective and clear promotion criteria/scheme should be adopted by the Institution.

fields.name: AREA III: CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
fields.description:
Curriculum and instruction occupy center stage in any educational program. These seek to research, develop, and implement curriculum changes that enhance student achievement within and outside of institutions. How students learn and the best ways to educate deserve much consideration.

The quality of these two allied areas determines primarily the prestige and strength of the Institution. Area of concern are on six parameters. These are encompassing which are: a) curriculum and program of studies; b) instructional process, methodologies, and learning opportunities; c) assessment of academic performance; d) classroom management; e) graduation requirements, and; f) administrative support for effective instruction.

fields.name: AREA IV: SUPPORT TO STUDENTS
fields.description: Students are the raison d' etre for the establishment of learning institutions. This, the school has the responsibility to support the family and other social institutions in the development of the total personality of the student. Towards this end, a program of student services is designed as an integral part of institutional effectiveness. All activities should be well-planned and implemented to assist the student to attain his/her maximum potential and become a worthy contributor in his/her social environment. Student support and services complement the Academic Program.

fields.name: AREA V: RESEARCH
fields.description:
Research is an avenue through which new knowledge is discovered, applied, or verified through which appropriate technologies are generated. Thus, it is a basic requirement for an educational institution to have a firmly established research and development program. Its thrusts and priorities should be congruent with those identified in the development plans of regional and national R and D-oriented agencies such as NEDA, DOST, CHED, etc.

The institutional leadership in research should be proactive and developmental in orientation. It must provide adequate and sustained budget allocation annually for the Academic Unit, Adequate physical facilities, laboratory equipment, and supplied for research should be provided. The Academic Unit has to maintain strong research with various R and D agencies locally and internationally.

fields.name: AREA VI: EXTENSION
fields.description:
The extension function makes the Institution's presence felt in the community. It involves the application of existing and new knowledge and technology and those generated in the Institution to improve the quality of life of the people. Through the extension program, people are empowered with appropriate knowledge, attitudes, and skills. Thus, extension services cater to various aspects of the community life, e.g., economic growth, promotion of health, environmental management, and social transformation.

The Institution plans and implements an extension program that is need- and client-based. This program should have a budgetary support and other resource allocations. The faculty members may serve as experts, consultants, organizers, facilitators, coordinators, service providers, and change agents in the community as forms of extension and community involvement.

Careful planning and coordination with other community outreach agencies should be considered to avoid duplication of services offered to the clientele.

fields.name: AREA VII: LIBRARY
fields.description:
The library is the heart of any learning institution. It is a synergy of people. hardware, and software whose purpose is to assist clients in using knowledge and technology to transform and improve their lives.

Information and knowledge are essential to the attainment of institutional goals. The ways in which they are selected, acquired, stored, accessed, and distributed within the institution will, in large measure, determine the success of teaching, research, and other academic endeavors. The Institution thrives on clear policies concerning access to, and provision of, information. Thus, the library must take an active role in the development and implementation of these policies.

Each institution has a unique vision, mission, goals, and objectives. These are influenced by its philosophy, geographical location, and social responsibility, Similarly, as a subsystem of the institution, the library has a unique role to perform.

fields.name: AREA VIII: PHYSICAL PLANT and FACILITIES
fields.description: The quality and adequacy of the physical plant and facilities of a learning institution determine to a large measure the successful implementation of its curricular programs. In a broad sense, physical plant and facilities include school campus, buildings and other physical infrastructures, equipment, and services that complement institutional and program effectiveness.

fields.name: AREA IX: LABORATORIES
fields.description: Laboratories are included in the support systems for any academic program. Broadly defined, they cover science laboratories, speech laboratories, demonstration farms, shops, and other facilities for practicum activities essential to the successful implementation of curricular programs inclusive of their use and functions.

fields.name: AREA X: ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The administration is the engine of the Institution in the attainment of its vision, mission, goals and objectives. It is concerned with the general affairs of the Institution and its organizational performance. Thus, the administration adopts institutional processes and ensures that said processes are satisfactorily implemented.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS AND PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE
fields.description: The faculty should have the appropriate academic preparation and experience relevant to the program. They must be holders of appropriate degrees. In case of any deficiency, they should possess relevant and/or compensatory qualifications. Moreover, they must be licensed (where applicable) if they are handling professional subjects. They must exhibit competence as evidenced by their professional license, performance evaluation, consultancy, and scholarly works.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: RECRUITMENT, SELECTION, and ORIENTATION
fields.description:
Recruitment and selection of the faculty are among the important activities undertaken by an Institution. Success in the implementation of an academic program depends to a great extent on the quality of the faculty.

The Institution should have an effective system of recruitment and selection of the most qualified faculty. The system may include the conduct of a psychological test, interview, demonstration teaching, etc. The process is a participative effort of the dean, chairperson, faculty representative/s, and other designated officials. New faculty members must be given orientation on the Institution's VMGO and policies, as well as on their responsibilities and privileges.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: FACULTY ADEQUACY AND LOADING
fields.description: The Institution should have an adequate number of faculty with the appropriate qualifications to handle the courses offered by a particular program. Teaching assignment/loading should be based on the major/minor fields of specialization of the faculty. Their workload should allow them time to prepare lessons, score papers and other course requirements, advise students, conduct research and extension activities, and perform other instruction-related activities and institutional service. If possible, the faculty should not be given more than three academic subject preparations.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: RANK AND TENURE
fields.description: The Institution should implement a system of promotion in rank and salary based on existing policies and guidelines. Faculty members must be informed of the institutional policies on probation, extension, renewal or termination of contract, promotion, and retirement.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: FACULTY DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: The Institution should have a well-funded Faculty Development Program. The program should include criteria for the selection of scholars/grantees, and opportunities/study privileges, research grants, training, etc., that are available. Faculty members should be encouraged to join professional organizations and to continuously upgrade their knowledge and competence by participating in in-service training activities such as seminars, conferences, workshops, etc.

fields.name: PARAMETER F: PROFESSIONAL PERFORMANCE and SCHOLARLY WORKS
fields.description: Teaching is the main function of the faculty and a performance evaluation system should be based on objective criteria. The faculty should also be involved in the dissemination of knowledge, innovations, and technologies in national and international fora and in the development of instructional materials such as modules, software, teachwares, multi-media devices, etc. Moreover, they are expected to render expert services and consultancies.

fields.name: PARAMETER G: SALARIES, FRINGE BENEFITS, and INCENTIVES
fields.description: The salary scale of the faculty follows the DBM Salary Standardization Scheme and the most recent government issuances on compensation. Fringe benefits of faculty members such as leave privileges and financial assistance should be embodied in the Institution's Code or Manual in consonance with CSC and other government policies and guidelines. Overloads are appropriately compensated. Outstanding performance (publication, reproduction, scholarly works, etc.) of faculty should be recognized and incentives be given correspondingly.

fields.name: PARAMETER H: PROFESSIONALISM
fields.description: Professionalism should be practiced based on the SUC Code, the Civil Service Code of Ethical Standards for Government Officials and Employees (RA 6713), and the Code of Ethics for the Profession. Academic freedom should be judiciously exercised.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The required number of faculty possess graduate degrees appropriate and relevant to the Graduate Education program, namely;

fields.name: S.1.1.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: CURRICULUM and PROGRAM of STUDIES
fields.description: The Curriculum must have content and design that will enable the students to achieve intended learning outcomes. It should work towards the attainment of the mission of the Institution, and the attainment of the course objectives. It should include recent developments in teaching and learning techniques, and other attributes necessary for employment, such as teamwork, communication, leadership skills, etc.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: INSTRUCTIONAL PROCESSES, METHODOLOGIES, and LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES
fields.description: The Instructional process should provide learning opportunities for the students. it should also make use of different strategies, methodologies, and techniques. Learning opportunities could be in the following areas: 1) teaching and learning; 2) professional development, and; 3) collaboration.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE
fields.description: Assessment is an integral part of a curricular program for purposes of continuous improvement. It is used to demonstrate how well the program carries out the mission of the Institution. The methods used for assessment should demonstrate reliable relationships between the educational experiences (curriculum) and the expected outcomes. Assessment may be done before, during, and after the implementation of the curricular program.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: MANAGEMENT OF LEARNING
fields.description: The rules and practices relating to classroom management should be conducive to effective instruction and should be carefully observed. Measures should be taken to ensure punctual attendance of faculty members in their scheduled classes. The rule on absences should follow the Institution's policy. Records of these absences should be kept.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: GRADUATION REQUIREMENTS
fields.description: Requirements for graduation are made clear and well-known to the students. Research, practicum, on-the-job training and other activities prescribed in the curriculum as requirements for graduation should be strictly implemented to further improve quality of graduates.

fields.name: PARAMETER F: ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FOR EFFECTIVE INSTRUCTION
fields.description:
Quality Instruction should be sustained by providing the required instructional materials like syllabi, assessment of instruments, etc., to make teaching-learning meaningful and fruitful. To ensure effective instruction, it is necessary that students and faculty are punctual in their respective classes. Likewise, this is sustained through utilization of updated/enhanced instructional materials like syllabi, examination questions and departmental examinations; provisions for substitutions and special arrangements fro absences or leaves of faculty members; and supervisory visits to monitor academic activities.

It is also desirable the researchers on correlational studies between faculty performance and student achievements be undertaken.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: STUDENT SERVICES PROGRAM
fields.description: There should be a well-organized, properly administered and adequately-staffed Student Services Program (SSP). Such a program should be provided with adequate services, physical facilities, and adequate resources to attain its objectives. A program of activities and services such as Student Welfare, Student Development, Institutional Student Programs and Services should be known and accepted by the administrators, faculty, and students.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: STUDENT WELFARE
fields.description:
The Student Welfare Services are basic services and programs needed to ensure and promote the well-being of students. These include Information, Orientation and Awareness, Guidance and Counseling, Career and Placement, Economic Enterprise Development, and Student Handbook Development.

A well-planned and functional Student Welfare Program directed towards the welfare and total personality development of students should be provided by the Institution.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: STUDENT DEVELOPMENT
fields.description:
Student Development is composed of programs and activities designed for the enhancement and deepening of leadership skills and social responsibility. This includes student organizations and activities, professional organization or societies, special interests, Leadership Training Programs, Student Council/Government, Student Discipline, Student Publication/Media.

A well-planned and well-implemented Student Development Program and activities would contribute to the development and enhancement of leadership effectiveness of students in the following: a.) governance; b.) discipline, and; c.) publication.

A well-organized and well-implemented essential services to the students would result to: a.) improved admission, safety and security, housing, health and food, and foreign student services; b.) effective scholarship and financial assistance to deserving students; c.) an environment conducive to free expression of one's religious orientation, and; d.) opportunities to develop and enhance talents, abilities, abilities for appreciation, promotion, and conservation of national culture and multi-cultural heritage, physical fitness and well-being, social awareness, and meaningful contribution to nation building.

fields.name: PARAMETER D.: INSTITUTIONAL PROGRAMS AND SERVICES
fields.description: These are programs and activities that would facilitate the delivery of essential services to the students, such as: a.) Admission; b.) Scholarship and Financial Assistance; 3.) Food; d.) Health; e.) Security and Safety; f.) Housing and Residential Services; g.) Multi-Faith; h.) Foreign Students; i.) Services for Students with Special Needs; j.) culture and arts; k.) sports; l.) social, and; m.) community involvement.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND EVALUATION
fields.description: The Institution should encourage the students to conduct research on student affairs and services program,. The results should be disseminated and utilized, monitoring and evaluation of student affairs and services can serve as feedback mechanism to ensure sustainability and effectiveness of the Student Affairs and Services program.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: PRIORITIES AND RELEVANCE
fields.description: The Institution shall conceptualize and implement identified researches (preferably multidisciplinary and collaborative in nature) in consonance with institutional, regional, and national priorities. The Institution's research should be consistent with its priorities and those emphasized in the Agenda of the DOST, CHED, NEDA, etc.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: FUNDING AND OTHER SOURCES
fields.description: The Institution shall be encouraged to allocate funds for research regularly. Resources from various local and foreign agencies should be explored to augment the Institution's appropriation. In-house reviews shall be conducted periodically. Research results are disseminated to local and national instrumentalitlies interested in collaborating with academic institutions.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING, EVALUATION, AND UTILIZATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS/OUTPUTS
fields.description: The faculty are required to undertake or conduct research especially in their fields of specialization to supplement and improve the teaching-learning process and satisfy one of the four-fold mandated functions of the Institution. To sustain the quality of researches, incentives through honoraria, grant of service credits, and work-load adjustments shall be accorded to the faculty who are conducting researches and publishing their outputs. Likewise, continuous upgrading of faculty and research staff is undertaken by the Institution to enhance research capabilities and competence. The conduct of department researches shall be encouraged in addition to specialized researches undertaken by the faculty. At best, a collective and/or collaborative research undertaken by the Institution/Academic Unit must be defined and focused. Moreover, completed researches shall be pilot-tested and eventually utilized.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: PUBLICATION AND DISSEMINATION
fields.description: Researches whether on the proposal, on-going, or completed stage may be published in the proper media and well disseminated to target clientele.The Institution implements incentive schemes for publication and paper presentation of research outputs in national and international fora.

fields.description: Extension services are provided by the Academic Unit in response to the needs and urgent concerns of the community it serves. Likewise, it takes into consideration local, regional, and national development thrusts. The services extended should be reflective of the Institution's vision, mission, goals, and objectives.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING, AND EVALUATION
fields.description: There is an extension unit which coordinates a functional extension program. Stakeholders, administration, faculty, and students are involved in the planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of extension activities. Multi-disciplinary or multi-sectoral approach is encouraged in the conduct of the various extension activities, including the assessment of the impact of each extension activity implemented for various clientele.

fields.description: The extension program is provided regularly with a definite budget to ensure its sustainability. Funds, as well as material and service inputs from the Institution or from other agencies, are needed in the implementation of a viable extension program.

The community should be invited to participate in the planning, implementing, monitoring, and evaluation of activities, as well as sourcing of funds and other resources.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: ADMINISTRATION
fields.description:
The library should be administered and supervised by a full-time, professional librarian with at least a Master's degree in Library and Information Science under a functional organizational set-up. It should be administered in a manner which allows and encourages the fullest and most effective use of available library resources.

The head librarian may have an academic rank )classified as academic non-teaching staff) and actively participates in curricular, instructional, and research matters. A Library Board/Committee should serve as a conduit between the library and its users. It should work towards the continued development and improvement of library resources and services.

The head librarian should develop a long range plan. He/She must have a systematic and continuous program for evaluating library performance. He/She must prepare systems and procedures for library operation and utilization in coordination with administration, the faculty and the students.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: PERSONNEL
fields.description: The library should have a sufficient staff of staff to organize and maintain the collection as well as to manage information and reference services for the clientele.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: COLLECTION DEVELOPMENT, ORGANIZATION, AND PRESERVATION
fields.description: The library's varied resources should be adequate to serve the Institution's instructional and research needs. It must have a system of progressive development and growth in accordance with the Institutional Development Plan.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: SERVICES AND UTILIZATION
fields.description: The overriding goal of the library is to provide services to the academic community. These services are measured by their effectiveness in meeting the users' needs.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: PHYSICAL SET-UP AND FACILITIES
fields.description: The library should provide adequate and appropriate space and facilities to serve the academic community. It should be strategically planned and functionally designed to allow for rearrangement and future expansion. A separate building for the library would be ideal.

fields.name: PARAMETER F: FINANCIAL SUPPORT
fields.description: The library should have a separate, realistic, and adequate budget to support its various activities and services. The budget proposal is prepared in consultation with the Library Board/Committee.

fields.name: PARAMETER G: LINKAGES
fields.description: A network of alliances/relationships extending beyond the Institution could enhance the library services. These linkages may be customary, contractual or cooperative. In collaboration with other libraries, it participates in activities that could enhance the attainment of its objectives.
