fields.name: PARAMETER B: ACADEMIC ADMINISTRATION
fields.description:
The area covers administrative and academic matters such as qualification of academic officials; recruitment and promotion of faculty and support staff; setting standards and targets; planning, implementing and monitoring of programs and other related activities; establishing linkages, partnerships and networking activities; professional growth development opportunities; proper use and maintenance of facilities, equipment, etc.; and generating resources and income and cost effective measures.

The quality of the curricular programs and the qualifications of the faculty to implement would determine the level of excellence attained by the Institution.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Dean/Academic Unit Head possess the required educational qualifications and experience needed to administer the College/Academic Unit as follows:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: holder of a doctoral degree in education or in related fields;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: must have a minimum teaching experience in graduate level of not less than five years and preferably, two years of administrative experience, and;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: with research experience and published works in professional journals.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Department Chair/s , or their equivalent has appropriate/relevant educational qualification and experience.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Dean is assisted by Department Chair/s or their equivalent with appropriate/relevant educational qualification and experience.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The Dean implements a supervisory program.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The Dean participates in the recruitment and promotion of the faculty.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The Dean, the faculty, and the administration work together for the improvement of the College/Academic Unit, particularly in:

fields.name: I.4.1.
fields.description: setting standards and targets;

fields.name: I.4.2.
fields.description: planning of programs and other related activities;

fields.name: I.4.3.
fields.description: implementing, monitoring, and evaluation of plans, programs, and other related activities;

fields.name: I.4.4.
fields.description: establishing linkages, partnerships, and networking activities;

fields.name: I.4.5.
fields.description: providing opportunities for professional growth and development for the faculty and staff;

fields.name: I.4.6.
fields.description: preparing policies and on the internal administration of the College/Academic Unit, and;

fields.name: I.4.7.
fields.description: preparing guidelines on the proper use and maintenance of facilities, equipment, supplies, and materials, etc.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: Definite criteria and procedures in the selection and promotion of the most qualified faculty and staff are observed.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: The Dean, faculty, staff, and students pursue collaborative activities in generating resources and income, and in implementing cost-effective measures.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: The Dean implements policies and procedures on internal administration and operations of the College/Academic Unit.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The College/Academic Unit is efficiently and effectively managed.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT
fields.description:
The business administration of the Institution should be well-maintained and managed by qualified and competent personnel. Business functions are well-delineated to promote fiscal integrity, economy, responsibility, and accountability.

Financial management includes budgeting, accounting, auditing, requisition and purchase of supplies, and the preparation of financial reports. The effectiveness in the performance of the business services and sound financial management are indicators of a healthy financial administration.

fields.description: The Institution has an approved Financial Development Plan (FDP).

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The approved budget is consonance with the FDP.

fields.name: S.3.2.

fields.name: S.3.3.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: SUPPLY MANAGEMENT
fields.description: Supplies support the operations of the Institution. The Institution therefore should have a scheme of managing supplies, materials, and equipment. While committees may assist the Institution in the procurement of these supplies/materials/equipment, a supply management office takes charge of their procurement distribution and storage.

fields.name: S.2.

fields.name: S.3.

fields.description: The Institution maintains a Supply Management Office (SMO) managed by qualified staff with specific functions and responsibilities.

fields.name: I.2.

fields.name: I.3.

fields.description: Records and reports include: minutes of the board meetings, minutes of faculty meetings, faculty directory; records of faculty training and experience; records of enrollment by class, gender, and course; students' directory; alumni directory, recorded data for statistical use; inventory of property; reports of administrative officials; summary of disciplinary matters; records of scholarships granted, etc. Adequate, accurate, accessible, up-to-date, and systematic records are indicators of sound records management.

fields.name: PARAMETER G: INSTITUTIONAL PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: Sound institutional planning should show concern for, and attention to, the following: congruence with the institutional vision and mission, academic unit's goals and program objectives; alignment with national, regional, and local goals and needs; adequate allocation of resources; participation of all sectors of the academic community in the planning process; formal documentation of all plans and progress of implementation; long- and short-term dimensions of planning; and mechanisms for periodic review, evaluation, and updating. A Planning Officer should be responsible for the coordination of the planning activity.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved Strategic Development Plan (SDP) available in printed and/or electronic forms.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a system of monitoring the implementation of the SDP.

fields.name: I.1.

fields.name: I.2.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The SDP is implemented, monitored, evaluated, reviewed , and updated regularly.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The SDP is congruent with the VMGO, as well as with the local, regional, and national development goals.

fields.name: PARAMETER H: PERFORMANCE OF ADMINISTRATIVE PERSONNEL
fields.description:
The administrative personnel should be qualified to perform the various administrative services. The performance evaluation of the personnel should include: 1) competence; 2) quality of work; 3) work ethic; 4) creative ability; 5) interpersonal relations, and; 6) ability to handle internal and external pressures.

The performance of the administrative personnel should be monitored and evaluated regularly.

The efficiency of the administrative set-up and harmonious relationship among the personnel are considered significant criteria for excellence.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved performance evaluation system for administrative personnel which includes the following items:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: competence;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: quality of work;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: work ethics (punctuality, wise use of time, etc.);

fields.name: S.1.4.
fields.description: creative ability and innovativeness;

fields.name: S.1.5.
fields.description: ability to handle internal and external pressures, and;

fields.name: S.1.6.
fields.description: interpersonal relations.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution regularly monitors and evaluates the performance of the administrative staff.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The results of performance evaluation of the administrative staff are utilized:

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: to improve performance and delivery of services, and;

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: for promotion.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The administrative personnel/staff have commendable performance.

fields.name: MSBio
fields.description: This contains all pertinent documents for the Level II Accreditation of the Master of Science in Biology.

fields.name: AREA I: VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES
fields.description: The area of Vision, Mission, Goals, and Objectives is the most fundamental of all the ten (10) areas to be surveyed. Everything in the Institution is justified only to the extent that it realizes its vision and mission. It is essential therefore for the Institution to formulate the vision and mission which should be the bases of all its operations. The Institution should be judged by the degree to which these are attained, not in comparison with the others.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: STATEMENT OF VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES
fields.description:
The Vision is the state the Institution hopes to become in the future. The MGO represents the hierarchy of aims of the institution. The Mission reflects the mandate /aim of the whole state university or state college. The Goals are the aims at the hierarchical structure below the institutional level  (the academic Unit/Institute/School); and the Objectives are the aims at the program level, i.e., what the program hopes to achieve.

The Institution shall define its mission in accordance with its legal and educational development mandate and the thrusts of the government.

The program outcomes are the foci of program accreditation. These are the competencies (knowledge and skills), values, and other attributes, which the Institution hopes their graduates shall acquire to enable them to compete for employment, locally and internationally.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has a system of determining its vision and mission.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Vision clearly reflects what the the Institution hopes to become in the future.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The Mission clearly reflects the Institution's legal and other statutory mandate.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: The Goals of the College/Academic Unit are consistent with the Mission of the Institution.

fields.name: S.5.
fields.description: The Objectives of the program have the expected outcomes in terms of competencies (skills and knowledge) values, and other attributes of the graduates, which include the development of:

fields.name: S.5.1.
fields.description: technical skills in Graduate education;

fields.name: S.5.2.
fields.description: research and extension capabilities;

fields.name: S.5.3.
fields.description: students' own ideas, desirable attitudes, and personal discipline

fields.name: S.5.4.
fields.description: moral character;

fields.name: S.5.5.
fields.description: critical, analytical, problem solving and other higher order thinking skills, and;

fields.name: S.5.6.
fields.description: aesthetic and cultural values.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution/Academic Unit conducts a review on the statement of the Vision and Mission as well as its goals and program objectives for the approval of authorities concerned.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The College/Academic Unit follows a system of formulating its goals and the objectives of the program.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The College's/Academic Unit's faculty, personnel, students, and other stakeholders (cooperating agencies, linkages, alumni, industry sector, and other concerned groups) participate in the formulation , review and/or revision of the VMGO.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: DISSEMINATION AND ACCEPTABILITY
fields.description:
It is expected that the Institution disseminates, and works for the acceptance of the Vision, Mission, Goals, and Objectives  by the stakeholders. In order to facilitate awareness and acceptance, it is a good practice that the faculty, non-teaching staff, students, linkages, the community, and other stakeholders are involved in the formulation, review and/or revision of the VMGO.

An outcomes-based assessment will focus on the extent to which the program objectives are attained as shown in the outcomes. Thus, there must be a common understanding and acceptance of the end results of the program by both the faculty and the students.

It should be demonstrated that the program objectives (outcomes) are consistent with the College goals; and the College goals with the Mission of the University. On a long-term perspective, the accomplishment of the Mission will lead to the realization of the Vision of the Institution.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The VMGO are available on bulletin boards, in catalogs/manuals, and in other forms of communication media.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: A system of dissemination and acceptability of the VMGO is enforced.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The administrators/faculty attend in-service seminars and training on awareness and acceptability of the:

fields.name: I.2.1.
fields.description: Vision and Mission of the Institution;

fields.name: I.2.2.
fields.description: Goals of the College/Academic Unit, and;

fields.name: I.2.3.
fields.description: Objectives of the Program.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The formulation/review/revision of the VMGO is participated in by the following:

fields.name: I.3.1.
fields.description: administrators;

fields.name: I.3.2.
fields.description: faculty;

fields.name: I.3.3.
fields.description: staff;

fields.name: I.3.4.
fields.description: students, and;

fields.name: I.3.5.
fields.description: other stakeholders.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The faculty and staff perform their jobs/functions in consonance With the VMGO.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The VMGO are widely disseminated to the different agencies, institutions, industry sector, and the community.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: There is full awareness and acceptance of the VMGO by the administrators, faculty, staff, students, and other stakeholders.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: There is congruence between actual educational practices and activities with the following:

fields.name: O.2.1.
fields.description: Vision and Mission of the SUC;

fields.name: O.2.2.
fields.description: Goals of the College/Academic Unit, and;

fields.name: O.2.3.
fields.description: Objectives of the Graduate Education program.

fields.name: O.3.
fields.description: The goals and objectives are being achieved.

fields.name: AREA II: FACULTY
fields.description:
The standard or quality of an Institution or Program is greatly measured by the qualifications of its faculty. In this light, the faculty should be composed of competent members in terms of academic qualifications, experience, and professional expertise. In addition, they should manifest desirable personal qualities and high level of professionalism.

To be effective, faculty members should be properly compensated and taken care of. They must be given opportunities for continuous personal and professional development. A policy of fair and equitable distribution of teaching assignments and workload should be practiced. Likewise, objective and clear promotion criteria/scheme should be adopted by the Institution.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: ACADEMIC QUALIFICATIONS AND PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE
fields.description: The faculty should have the appropriate academic preparation and experience relevant to the program. They must be holders of appropriate degrees. In case of any deficiency, they should possess relevant and/or compensatory qualifications. Moreover, they must be licensed (where applicable) if they are handling professional subjects. They must exhibit competence as evidenced by their professional license, performance evaluation, consultancy, and scholarly works.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The required number of faculty possess graduate degrees appropriate and relevant to the Graduate Education program, namely;

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: For a Master degree program in Teacher Education, at least five full-time faculty members who have published works in professional journals;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: Of the five, at least two are doctoral degree holders;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: At least three of the full-time faculty members have advanced training in the major area being offered;

fields.name: S.1.4.
fields.description: Of the three, at least one has a doctoral degree in the major area being offered;

fields.name: S.1.5.
fields.description: For doctoral program, there must be at least five faculty who are doctoral degree holders and who have published worked in refereed professional journals, and;

fields.name: S.1.6.
fields.description: At least three of the five have advanced training in the major area being offered.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: Other qualification such as the following are considered:

fields.name: S.2.1.
fields.description: Related professional experience;

fields.name: S.2.2.
fields.description: Technical skills and competence, and;

fields.name: S.2.3.
fields.description: Special abilities, computer literacy, research productivity

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: All faculty handling Teacher Education courses are Professional Teachers registered with the PRC.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: The Institution has consortium programs with other recognized institutions to strengthen faculty resources.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The faculty demonstrate professional competence and are engaged in any or a combination of the following:

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: instruction;

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: research;

fields.name: I.1.3.
fields.description: extension;

fields.name: I.1.4.
fields.description: production;

fields.name: I.1.5.
fields.description: consultancy and expert service, and;

fields.name: I.1.6.
fields.description: publication, creative, and scholarly work.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The Institution has qualified and competent faculty.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: RECRUITMENT, SELECTION, and ORIENTATION
fields.description:
Recruitment and selection of the faculty are among the important activities undertaken by an Institution. Success in the implementation of an academic program depends to a great extent on the quality of the faculty.

The Institution should have an effective system of recruitment and selection of the most qualified faculty. The system may include the conduct of a psychological test, interview, demonstration teaching, etc. The process is a participative effort of the dean, chairperson, faculty representative/s, and other designated officials. New faculty members must be given orientation on the Institution's VMGO and policies, as well as on their responsibilities and privileges.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: There is an Institutional Human Resources Development Plan/Program designed for faculty recruitment.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: Recruitment and selection of faculty is processed by the Faculty Selection Board using the following criteria:

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: academic qualifications;

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: personal qualities;

fields.name: I.1.3.
fields.description: communication skills;

fields.name: I.1.4.
fields.description: teaching ability;

fields.name: I.1.5.
fields.description: medical examination results;

fields.name: I.1.6.
fields.description: psychological examination results;

fields.name: I.1.7.
fields.description: relevant professional experiences (if any);

fields.name: I.1.8.
fields.description: previous record of employment (if any);

fields.name: I.1.9.
fields.description: technical/special skills and abilities, and;

fields.name: I.1.10.
fields.description: previous performance rating (if any).

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The hiring system adopts an open competitive selection, based on the CSC-approved Merit Systems and Promotion Plan of the Institution published and well-disseminated through various means of communication:

fields.name: I.2.1.

fields.name: I.2.2.

fields.name: I.2.3.
fields.description: website, and;

fields.name: I.2.4.

fields.name: I.2.5.
fields.description: others (please specify).

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: A Screening Committee selects and recommends the best and most qualified applicant.

fields.name: I.4.

fields.name: I.5.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: the most qualified faculty are selected.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: FACULTY ADEQUACY AND LOADING
fields.description: The Institution should have an adequate number of faculty with the appropriate qualifications to handle the courses offered by a particular program. Teaching assignment/loading should be based on the major/minor fields of specialization of the faculty. Their workload should allow them time to prepare lessons, score papers and other course requirements, advise students, conduct research and extension activities, and perform other instruction-related activities and institutional service. If possible, the faculty should not be given more than three academic subject preparations.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: Faulty-student ratio is in accordance with the program requirements and standards as follows:

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a provision for incentives of overload teaching in accordance with the CMO of the program and/or Institutional guidelines.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The faculty members are assigned to courses where they have the most expertise and training.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: Faculty schedule has time for preparation of lessons, scoring of test papers, record-keeping, class evaluation, and other instruction-related activities.

fields.name: S.5.
fields.description: Workload Guidelines contain sufficient time for teaching and/or research, extension, production, and other assigned tasks.

fields.name: S.6.
fields.description: There is equitable, measurable, and fair distribution of teaching load and other assignments.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: the maximum total load of a regular full-time faculty member in the graduate level is six units per term. This load, including other assignments at the undergraduate level, is based on the CMO and/or Institutional guidelines.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: A Faculty Manual is published formalizing faculty policies, standards, and guidelines.

fields.name: I.3.

fields.name: I.4.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: Administrative arrangements are adopted whenever vacancies/leaves of absence occur during the term.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: Administration, research, or professional assignments outside of regular teaching is given credits.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: Consultation, tutorial, remedial classes, expert services, and other instruction-related activities are given credits.

fields.name: O.1.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: RANK AND TENURE
fields.description: The Institution should implement a system of promotion in rank and salary based on existing policies and guidelines. Faculty members must be informed of the institutional policies on probation, extension, renewal or termination of contract, promotion, and retirement.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: the Institution has a system of promotion in rank and tenure based on official issuances.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Institution has a policy on probationary status of employment.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution implements the system of promotion in rank and salary based on existing policies and issuances (e.g. NBC 461).

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: Retirement, separation, or termination benefits are implemented in accordance with Institutional and government (CSC, GSIS/DBM} policies and guidelines.

fields.name: I.3.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The faculty concerned us officially informed of the extension, renewal, or termination of their appointments.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The Institution implements a CSC-approved Strategic Performance Management System (SPMS) which emphasizes quality teaching performance, research, creative work, extension, and production services.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The faculty are satisfied with their rank and employment status.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: FACULTY DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: The Institution should have a well-funded Faculty Development Program. The program should include criteria for the selection of scholars/grantees, and opportunities/study privileges, research grants, training, etc., that are available. Faculty members should be encouraged to join professional organizations and to continuously upgrade their knowledge and competence by participating in in-service training activities such as seminars, conferences, workshops, etc.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved and sustainable Faculty Development Plan (FDP).

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There are policies on faculty academic recognition and grant of scholarships/fellowships, and awards,

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: Every faculty member has at least one active membership in professional/scientific organizations or honor society relevant to his/her assignment and field of specialization.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: The budget allocation for faculty development is adequate.

The faculty should also be involved in the dissemination of knowledge, innovations, and technologies in national and international fora and in the development of instructional materials such as modules, software, teachwares, multi-media devices, etc. Moreover, they are expected to render expert services and consultancies.

fields.name: PARAMETER H: PROFESSIONALISM
fields.description: Professionalism should be practiced based on the SUC Code, the Civil Service Code of Ethical Standards for Government Officials and Employees (RA 6713), and the Code of Ethics for the Profession. Academic freedom should be judiciously exercised.

fields.name: AREA III: CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
fields.description:
Curriculum and instruction occupy center stage in any educational program. These seek to research, develop, and implement curriculum changes that enhance student achievement within and outside of institutions. How students learn and the best ways to educate deserve much consideration.

The quality of these two allied areas determines primarily the prestige and strength of the Institution. Area of concern are on six parameters. These are encompassing which are: a) curriculum and program of studies; b) instructional process, methodologies, and learning opportunities; c) assessment of academic performance; d) classroom management; e) graduation requirements, and; f) administrative support for effective instruction.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: CURRICULUM and PROGRAM of STUDIES
fields.description: The Curriculum must have content and design that will enable the students to achieve intended learning outcomes. It should work towards the attainment of the mission of the Institution, and the attainment of the course objectives. It should include recent developments in teaching and learning techniques, and other attributes necessary for employment, such as teamwork, communication, leadership skills, etc.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: Graduate education being the apex of the educational system, its curriculum showcases the best of the academic and intellectual products and processes of the system through the development of the following competencies:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: acquisition of advanced knowledge and theories based on the field of specialization;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: application of theories to actual problems in the field;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: demonstrating enhanced skills to carry out the application or strategy in the actual complex work settings.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a system of validation of subjects taken from other schools.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The curriculum reflects the local, regional, and national development goals as well as the Institution's vision and mission.

fields.name: I.1.1.

fields.description: The Instructional process should provide learning opportunities for the students. it should also make use of different strategies, methodologies, and techniques. fields.name: PARAMETER C: ASSESSMENT OF ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE
fields.description: Assessment is an integral part of a curricular program for purposes of continuous improvement. It is used to demonstrate how well the program carries out the mission of the Institution. The methods used for assessment should demonstrate reliable relationships between the educational experiences (curriculum) and the expected outcomes. Assessment may be done before, during, and after the implementation of the curricular program.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The program of studies has a system of evaluating the student performance through a combination of the following:

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: project and term papers;

fields.name: S.1.4.
fields.description: practicum and performance tests, and;

fields.name: S.1.5.
fields.description: other course requirements.

fields.name: S.2.1.

fields.name: S.2.2.

fields.description: The rules and practices relating to classroom management should be conducive to effective instruction and should be carefully observed. Measures should be taken to ensure punctual attendance of faculty members in their scheduled classes. The rule on absences should follow the Institution's policy. Records of these absences should be kept.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: GRADUATION REQUIREMENTS

fields.name: PARAMETER F: ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FOR EFFECTIVE INSTRUCTION
fields.description:
Quality Instruction should be sustained by providing the required instructional materials like syllabi, assessment of instruments, etc., to make teaching-learning meaningful and fruitful. To ensure effective instruction, it is necessary that students and faculty are punctual in their respective classes. Likewise, this is sustained through utilization of updated/enhanced instructional materials like syllabi, examination questions and departmental examinations; provisions for substitutions and special arrangements fro absences or leaves of faculty members; and supervisory visits to monitor academic activities.

It is also desirable the researchers on correlational studies between faculty performance and student achievements be undertaken.

fields.name: AREA IV: SUPPORT TO STUDENTS
fields.description: Students are the raison d' etre for the establishment of learning institutions. This, the school has the responsibility to support the family and other social institutions in the development of the total personality of the student. Towards this end, a program of student services is designed as an integral part of institutional effectiveness. All activities should be well-planned and implemented to assist the student to attain his/her maximum potential and become a worthy contributor in his/her social environment. Student support and services complement the Academic Program.

A program of activities and services such as Student Welfare, Student Development, Institutional Student Programs and Services should be known and accepted by the administrators, faculty, and students.

A well-planned and functional Student Welfare Program directed towards the welfare and total personality development of students should be provided by the Institution.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: STUDENT DEVELOPMENT
fields.description:
Student Development is composed of programs and activities designed for the enhancement and deepening of leadership skills and social responsibility. This includes student organizations and activities, professional organization or societies, special interests, Leadership Training Programs, Student Council/Government, Student Discipline, Student Publication/Media.

A well-planned and well-implemented Student Development Program and activities would contribute to the development and enhancement of leadership effectiveness of students in the following: a.) governance; b.) discipline, and; c.) publication.

A well-organized and well-implemented essential services to the students would result to: a.) improved admission, safety and security, housing, health and food, and foreign student services; b.) effective scholarship and financial assistance to deserving students; c.) an environment conducive to free expression of one's religious orientation, and; d.) opportunities to develop and enhance talents, abilities, abilities for appreciation, promotion, and conservation of national culture and multi-cultural heritage, physical fitness and well-being, social awareness, and meaningful contribution to nation building.

fields.name: AREA V: RESEARCH
fields.description:
Research is an avenue through which new knowledge is discovered, applied, or verified through which appropriate technologies are generated. Thus, it is a basic requirement for an educational institution to have a firmly established research and development program. Its thrusts and priorities should be congruent with those identified in the development plans of regional and national R and D-oriented agencies such as NEDA, DOST, CHED, etc.

The institutional leadership in research should be proactive and developmental in orientation. It must provide adequate and sustained budget allocation annually for the Academic Unit, Adequate physical facilities, laboratory equipment, and supplied for research should be provided. The Academic Unit has to maintain strong research with various R and D agencies locally and internationally.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: PRIORITIES AND RELEVANCE
fields.description: The Institution shall conceptualize and implement identified researches (preferably multidisciplinary and collaborative in nature) in consonance with institutional, regional, and national priorities. The Institution's research should be consistent with its priorities and those emphasized in the Agenda of the DOST, CHED, NEDA, etc.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution's research agenda is in consonance with institutional, regional, and national priorities concerned such as DOST, CHED-National Higher Education Research Agenda, NEDA, etc.

fields.name: S.2.

fields.name: I.1.

fields.name: I.2.

fields.name: I.2.1.
fields.description: administrators;

fields.name: I.2.2.
fields.description: faculty;

fields.name: I.2.3.
fields.description: students;

fields.name: I.2.4.
fields.description: government agency representatives (DOST, CHED, NEDA, etc.,), and;

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: Action researches to test theory in practice are conducted by faculty and students.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: Team/collaborative and interdisciplinary research is encouraged.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: Research outputs are published in refereed national and/or international journals.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: Priority researches are identified and conducted.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: Research results are published.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: FUNDING AND OTHER SOURCES
fields.description: The Institution shall be encouraged to allocate funds for research regularly. Resources from various local and foreign agencies should be explored to augment the Institution's appropriation. In-house reviews shall be conducted periodically. Research results are disseminated to local and national instrumentalitlies interested in collaborating with academic institutions.

fields.name: S.2.1.

fields.name: S.2.2.
fields.description: research staff;

fields.name: S.2.3.
fields.description: supplied and materials, and;

fields.name: S.2.4.
fields.description: workplace.

fields.description: allocates adequate funds for the conduct of faculty and student research;

fields.name: I.2.

fields.name: I.3.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING, EVALUATION, AND UTILIZATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS/OUTPUTS
fields.description: The faculty are required to undertake or conduct research especially in their fields of specialization to supplement and improve the teaching-learning process and satisfy one of the four-fold mandated functions of the Institution. To sustain the quality of researches, incentives through honoraria, grant of service credits, and work-load adjustments shall be accorded to the faculty who are conducting researches and publishing their outputs. Likewise, continuous upgrading of faculty and research staff is undertaken by the Institution to enhance research capabilities and competence. The conduct of department researches shall be encouraged in addition to specialized researches undertaken by the faculty. At best, a collective and/or collaborative research undertaken by the Institution/Academic Unit must be defined and focused. Moreover, completed researches shall be pilot-tested and eventually utilized.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: There is a system of implementation, monitoring, evaluation, and utilization of research outputs.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a policy on Intellectual Property Rights (IPR).

fields.name: AREA VI: EXTENSION
fields.description:
The extension function makes the Institution's presence felt in the community. It involves the application of existing and new knowledge and technology and those generated in the Institution to improve the quality of life of the people. Through the extension program, people are empowered with appropriate knowledge, attitudes, and skills. Thus, extension services cater to various aspects of the community life, e.g., economic growth, promotion of health, environmental management, and social transformation.

The Institution plans and implements an extension program that is need- and client-based. This program should have a budgetary support and other resource allocations. The faculty members may serve as experts, consultants, organizers, facilitators, coordinators, service providers, and change agents in the community as forms of extension and community involvement.

Careful planning and coordination with other community outreach agencies should be considered to avoid duplication of services offered to the clientele.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: PRIORITIES AND RELEVANCE
fields.description: Extension services are provided by the Academic Unit in response to the needs and urgent concerns of the community it serves. Likewise, it takes into consideration local, regional, and national development thrusts. The services extended should be reflective of the Institution's vision, mission, goals, and objectives.

fields.name: S.1.

fields.name: S.2.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The extension program reflects the VMGO.

Stakeholders, administration, faculty, and students are involved in the planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of extension activities. Multi-disciplinary or multi-sectoral approach is encouraged in the conduct of the various extension activities, including the assessment of the impact of each extension activity implemented for various clientele.

fields.name: AREA VII: LIBRARY
fields.description:
The library is the heart of any learning institution. It is a synergy of people. hardware, and software whose purpose is to assist clients in using knowledge and technology to transform and improve their lives.

Information and knowledge are essential to the attainment of institutional goals. The ways in which they are selected, acquired, stored, accessed, and distributed within the institution will, in large measure, determine the success of teaching, research, and other academic endeavors. The Institution thrives on clear policies concerning access to, and provision of, information. Thus, the library must take an active role in the development and implementation of these policies.

Each institution has a unique vision, mission, goals, and objectives. These are influenced by its philosophy, geographical location, and social responsibility, Similarly, as a subsystem of the institution, the library has a unique role to perform.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: ADMINISTRATION
fields.description:
The library should be administered and supervised by a full-time, professional librarian with at least a Master's degree in Library and Information Science under a functional organizational set-up. It should be administered in a manner which allows and encourages the fullest and most effective use of available library resources.

The head librarian may have an academic rank )classified as academic non-teaching staff) and actively participates in curricular, instructional, and research matters. A Library Board/Committee should serve as a conduit between the library and its users. It should work towards the continued development and improvement of library resources and services.

The head librarian should develop a long range plan. He/She must have a systematic and continuous program for evaluating library performance. He/She must prepare systems and procedures for library operation and utilization in coordination with administration, the faculty and the students.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The organizational structure of the library is well-defined.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The development of the library goals and objectives is the responsibility of the library head and staff with the approval of the Head of the institution.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: There is a Library Board/Committee which sets library policies, rules and procedures, and periodically reviews them.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: There is a duly approved and widely disseminated Library Manual or written policies and procedures covering the library's internal administration and operation.

fields.name: I.2.2.

fields.name: I.3.

In collaboration with other libraries, it participates in activities that could enhance the attainment of its objectives.

fields.description: The Library is on the mailing list of agencies, foundations, etc., for exchange of publications and other books and journals donations.

fields.name: I.1.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The library establishes consortia, networking, and resource sharing with other institutions and library collaborative activities.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: Library resource sharing and linkages are well-established.

fields.name: AREA VIII: PHYSICAL PLANT and FACILITIES
fields.description: The quality and adequacy of the physical plant and facilities of a learning institution determine to a large measure the successful implementation of its curricular programs. In a broad sense, physical plant and facilities include school campus, buildings and other physical infrastructures, equipment, and services that complement institutional and program effectiveness.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: CAMPUS
fields.description:
The site should be located in a wholesome environment, safe from traffic and transportation hazards, sufficiently free from noise, dust, smoke, and other undesirable elements. It should be provided with adequate facilities for drainage and sewage disposal. It should be adequate to meet the needs of the present school population and its future expansion. The school should be accessible to present and anticipated school population by means of public and private transportation. It should have satisfactory road network and sidewalks.

The campus should be so planned that it would be adequate for the intellectual, social, physical, and cultural interests of the Institution. It should be kept in good condition and physical appearance.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: There is a Site Development Plan and program of implementation.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Campus has accessible good roads and pathways.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The campus is in a well-planned, clean, and properly landscaped environment.

fields.name: S.4.
fields.description: There is a system to ensure that all of the following are provided:

fields.name: S.4.1.
fields.description: traffic safety in and outside the campus;

fields.name: S.4.2.
fields.description: waste management program;

fields.name: S.4.3.
fields.description: proper utilization, repair, and upkeep of school facilities and equipment, and;

fields.name: S.4.4.
fields.description: cleanliness and orderliness of the school campus.

fields.name: S.5.
fields.description: An area for outdoor educational activities, e.g. social, physical, athletic, cultural, military training, etc., exists.

fields.name: S.6.
fields.description: There is a campus security unit that ensures safety of the academic community.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The site infrastructure development plan is implemented as planned.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The site plan is strategically displayed inside the campus indicating the location of the different buildings, driveways, parking areas, etc.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The infrastructure development plan is implemented in accordance with approved zoning ordinances.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: Covered walks are  to protect the academic community from inclement weather.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The Institution implements a Waste Management Program.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: The Maintenance Unit or its equivalent periodically inspects school facilities and equipment to ensure their proper utilization and upkeep.

fields.description: The Campus environment is conducive to all educational activities.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: The site can accommodate its present school population and future expansion.

fields.name: O.3.
fields.description: The campus is safe and well-maintained.

fields.name: O.4.
fields.description: The campus is well-planned, clean, and properly landscaped.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: BUILDINGS
fields.description:
The buildings should be functionally designed and constructed of strong and durable materials to withstand natural calamities like earthquakes, typhoons, and fire. Their design should be pleasing to the eye and in conformity with the surroundings. At the same time, these are imbued with the proper atmosphere conducive to learning. Likewise, there should be provisions for disabled persons.

They should anticipate to accommodate future expansion needs, Entrance and exit points should be well-planned to insure sage and convenient mobility of the school population and the transacting public.

Stairways and fire exits should be adequate and standard in size and number, and conveniently located. No obstruction along the corridors impede the free flow of movement and physical activity.

fields.description: The buildings meet all requirements of the Building Code, A Certificate of Occupancy for each building is conspicuously displayed.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The buildings are constructed according to their respective uses.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The buildings are well-planned and appropriately located to provide for future expansion.

Classrooms should be adequately equipped with the required furniture, blackboards/whiteboards, and should have a pleasant atmosphere. Lighting, ventilation, general appearance, and acoustics should be satisfactory.

Athletic facilities should be accessible to the students, and must be sufficient in number and variety, depending on the requirements of the school population, There should be suitable arrangments for athletic activities during the rainy season.

It should be spacious enough to accommodate the five distinct sections: 1) reception area; 2) examination room; 3) treatment room; 4) dental section, and; 5) rest/recovery room, separate for male and female. It should be provided with basic equipment, medical supplies, beds, cabinets, and linen.

fields.description: Laboratories are included in the support systems for any academic program. Broadly defined, they cover science laboratories, speech laboratories, demonstration farms, shops, and other facilities for practicum activities essential to the successful implementation of curricular programs inclusive of their use and functions.

fields.name: AREA X: ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The administration is the engine of the Institution in the attainment of its vision, mission, goals and objectives. It is concerned with the general affairs of the Institution and its organizational performance. Thus, the administration adopts institutional processes and ensures that said processes are satisfactorily implemented.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: ORGANIZATION
fields.description: An educational institution should have a Governing Board of Regents/Trustees. This Board has the responsibility to formulate general policies. The policies should be implemented by a sufficient number of qualified officials duly appointed/designated for the purpose. A detailed description of the organizational set-up of the whole institution under survey should be found in an official document.

fields.name: S.1.

fields.name: S.2.

fields.name: PARAMETER B: ACADEMIC ADMINISTRATION
fields.description:
The area covers administrative and academic matters such as qualification of academic officials; recruitment and promotion of faculty and support staff; setting standards and targets; planning, implementing and monitoring of programs and other related activities; establishing linkages, partnerships and networking activities; professional growth development opportunities; proper use and maintenance of facilities, equipment, etc.; and generating resources and income and cost effective measures.

The quality of the curricular programs and the qualifications of the faculty to implement would determine the level of excellence attained by the Institution.

fields.description: holder of a doctoral degree in education or in related fields;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: must have a minimum teaching experience in graduate level of not less than five years and preferably, two years of administrative experience, and;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: with research experience and published works in professional journals.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Department Chair/s , or their equivalent has appropriate/relevant educational qualification and experience.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Dean is assisted by Department Chair/s or their equivalent with appropriate/relevant educational qualification and experience.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The Dean implements a supervisory program.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The Dean participates in the recruitment and promotion of the faculty.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The Dean, the faculty, and the administration work together for the improvement of the College/Academic Unit, particularly in:

fields.name: I.4.1.
fields.description: setting standards and targets;

fields.name: I.4.2.
fields.description: planning of programs and other related activities;

fields.name: I.4.3.
fields.description: implementing, monitoring, and evaluation of plans, programs, and other related activities;

fields.name: I.4.4.
fields.description: establishing linkages, partnerships, and networking activities;

fields.name: I.4.5.
fields.description: providing opportunities for professional growth and development for the faculty and staff;

fields.name: I.4.6.
fields.description: preparing policies and on the internal administration of the College/Academic Unit, and;

fields.name: I.4.7.
fields.description: preparing guidelines on the proper use and maintenance of facilities, equipment, supplies, and materials, etc.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: Definite criteria and procedures in the selection and promotion of the most qualified faculty and staff are observed.

fields.name: I.6.
fields.description: The Dean, faculty, staff, and students pursue collaborative activities in generating resources and income, and in implementing cost-effective measures.

fields.name: I.7.
fields.description: The Dean implements policies and procedures on internal administration and operations of the College/Academic Unit.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The College/Academic Unit is efficiently and effectively managed.

fields.name: PARAMETER C: STUDENT ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The following activities fall under this Area: admission and retention policies; registration, school fees, academic load, transfers, residence, course work, scholastic and graduation requirements, examination and grading system, scholarship/grants, shifting ang adding/dropping of course, code of conduct and discipline, availability of a student handbook, and organization of the recorded data for statistical use.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved and printed Student Handbook/Manual containing policies and guidelines on the following aspects of student life:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: admission and retention policies;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: registration requirements;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: school fees;

fields.name: S.1.4.
fields.description: academic load;

fields.name: S.1.5.
fields.description: transfers;

fields.name: S.1.6.
fields.description: residence, course work, scholastic, and graduation requirements;

fields.name: S.1.7.
fields.description: examinations and grading system;

fields.name: S.1.8.
fields.description: scholarships/grants/assistantships;

fields.name: S.1.9.
fields.description: shifting and adding/dropping of course/s/subject/s;

fields.name: S.1.10.
fields.description: code of conduct and discipline;

fields.name: S.1.11.
fields.description: attendance, and;

fields.name: S.1.12.
fields.description: others (please specify).

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: Students are provided opportunities to participate in the planning and implementation of activities concerning their welfare.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: Concerned officials, faculty, and staff act promptly on requests, needs, and problems of the students.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The administration, faculty, staff, and students work harmoniously and maintain good relationship.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an effective and functional student administration.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: Policy implementation is efficient.

fields.name: PARAMETER D: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT
fields.description:
The business administration of the Institution should be well-maintained and managed by qualified and competent personnel. Business functions are well-delineated to promote fiscal integrity, economy, responsibility, and accountability.

Financial management includes budgeting, accounting, auditing, requisition and purchase of supplies, and the preparation of financial reports. The effectiveness in the performance of the business services and sound financial management are indicators of a healthy financial administration.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved Financial Development Plan (FDP).

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The approved budget is consonance with the FDP.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The Institution has specific budgetary allotment for the following:

fields.name: S.3.1.
fields.description: personnel services;

fields.name: S.3.2.
fields.description: Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses (MOOE);

fields.name: S.3.3.
fields.description: capital outlay, and;

fields.name: S.3.4.
fields.description: special projects.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution maintains a Financial Management Office managed by qualified and competent staff.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The financial management staff is responsible for the efficient management of financial resources/funds of the institution.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The administrative officials, faculty, staff, and student representatives participate in the budget preparation and in the procurement program of the Institution.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The budget of the Institution is fairly and objectively allocated.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: The Institution allocates funds for the following student services and activities:

fields.name: I.5.1.
fields.description: culture development;

fields.name: I.5.2.
fields.description: athletic and sports development;

fields.name: I.5.3.
fields.description: medical and dental services;

fields.name: I.5.4.
fields.description: library;

fields.name: I.5.5.
fields.description: student body organization;

fields.name: I.5.6.
fields.description: guidance and counseling;

fields.name: I.5.7.
fields.description: improvement of laboratories/shops;

fields.name: I.5.8.
fields.description: repair and maintenance of facilities and equipment;

fields.name: I.5.9.
fields.description: purchase of new equipment, supplies, and materials;

fields.name: I.5.10.
fields.description: replacement of old and unserviceable equipment;

fields.name: I.5.11.
fields.description: construction of new facilities;

fields.name: I.5.12.
fields.description: improvement/expansion of physical plant;

fields.name: I.5.13.
fields.description: extension and community services;

fields.name: I.5.14.
fields.description: disaster and risk reduction, and;

fields.name: I.5.15.
fields.description: auxiliary services.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The Institution has a sound and effective financial management system.

fields.name: PARAMETER E: SUPPLY MANAGEMENT
fields.description: Supplies support the operations of the Institution. The Institution therefore should have a scheme of managing supplies, materials, and equipment. While committees may assist the Institution in the procurement of these supplies/materials/equipment, a supply management office takes charge of their procurement distribution and storage.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved procurement management system in consonance with the Revised RA 9184 (Government Procurement Reform Act).

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Institution has a system of proper disposal on non-serviceable and condemned equipment, supplies, and materials.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: The office has a storeroom for keeping and securing equipment, supplies, and material purchased.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution maintains a Supply Management Office (SMO) managed by qualified staff with specific functions and responsibilities.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The Bids and Awards Committee is responsible for the procurement and deliveries of needed equipment, supplies, and other materials in accordance with recent procurement policies and official issuances.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The Bids and Awards Committee (BAC) performs its tasks and responsibilities in accordance with recent procurement policies and official issuances.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The SMO prepares, evaluates, and submits the annual inventory of serviceable and non-serviceable facilities and equipment.

fields.name: I.5.
fields.description: All approved requests and procurement are published in Philippine Government Electronic Procurement System (PhilGEPS).

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an efficient and effective Supply Management System.

fields.name: O.2.
fields.description: All procurement transactions are transparent.

fields.name: PARAMETER F: RECORDS MANAGEMENT
fields.description: Records and reports include: minutes of the board meetings, minutes of faculty meetings, faculty directory; records of faculty training and experience; records of enrollment by class, gender, and course; students' directory; alumni directory, recorded data for statistical use; inventory of property; reports of administrative officials; summary of disciplinary matters; records of scholarships granted, etc. Adequate, accurate, accessible, up-to-date, and systematic records are indicators of sound records management.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has a system of records keeping.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: The Institution has policies and procedures to ensure the security and confidentiality of records.

fields.name: S.3.
fields.description: Policies and procedures on prompt release of records are in place.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution maintains a Records Management Office (RMO) managed by a qualified Records Officer.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: A records system us installed in offices where it allows access to information needed by concerned parties.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The Human Resource Management Office (HRMO) maintains accurate, up-to-date and systematic records of faculty and staff.

fields.name: I.4.
fields.description: The following updated records are made available to concerned parties:

fields.name: I.4.1.
fields.description: minutes of the Board of Regents/Trustees meetings;

fields.name: I.4.2.
fields.description: minutes of the faculty meetings, e.g. minutes of the Academic Council meetings;

fields.name: I.4.3.
fields.description: faculty/staff individual files;

fields.name: I.4.4.
fields.description: faculty/staff performance evaluation results, and;

fields.name: I.4.5.
fields.description: other records such as:

fields.name: I.4.5.1.
fields.description: student directory;

fields.name: I.4.5.2.
fields.description: alumni directory;

fields.name: I.4.5.3.
fields.description: permanent records of students;

fields.name: I.4.5.4.
fields.description: reports of Director/Dean;

fields.name: I.4.5.5.
fields.description: annual reports;

fields.name: I.4.5.6.
fields.description: accomplishment/progress reports;

fields.name: I.4.5.7.
fields.description: scholarship records;

fields.name: I.4.5.8.
fields.description: statistical data;

fields.name: I.4.5.9.
fields.description: financial records of students;

fields.name: I.4.5.10.
fields.description: inventory of property, and;

fields.name: I.4.5.11.
fields.description: proceedings of administrative investigation (if any).

fields.name: I.4.5.12.
fields.description: others (please specify.)

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The Institution had a commendable Records Management System.

fields.name: PARAMETER G: INSTITUTIONAL PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
fields.description: Sound institutional planning should show concern for, and attention to, the following: congruence with the institutional vision and mission, academic unit's goals and program objectives; alignment with national, regional, and local goals and needs; adequate allocation of resources; participation of all sectors of the academic community in the planning process; formal documentation of all plans and progress of implementation; long- and short-term dimensions of planning; and mechanisms for periodic review, evaluation, and updating. A Planning Officer should be responsible for the coordination of the planning activity.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved Strategic Development Plan (SDP) available in printed and/or electronic forms.

fields.name: S.2.
fields.description: There is a system of monitoring the implementation of the SDP.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution's Planning and Development Unit plans, monitors, and evaluates planned activities and targets.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The planning process is a cooperative and participative endeavor of the administration, the faculty, staff, and the students.

fields.name: I.3.
fields.description: The SDP is implemented, monitored, evaluated, reviewed , and updated regularly.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The SDP is congruent with the VMGO, as well as with the local, regional, and national development goals.

fields.name: PARAMETER H: PERFORMANCE OF ADMINISTRATIVE PERSONNEL
fields.description:
The administrative personnel should be qualified to perform the various administrative services. The performance evaluation of the personnel should include: 1) competence; 2) quality of work; 3) work ethic; 4) creative ability; 5) interpersonal relations, and; 6) ability to handle internal and external pressures.

The performance of the administrative personnel should be monitored and evaluated regularly.

The efficiency of the administrative set-up and harmonious relationship among the personnel are considered significant criteria for excellence.

fields.name: S.1.
fields.description: The Institution has an approved performance evaluation system for administrative personnel which includes the following items:

fields.name: S.1.1.
fields.description: competence;

fields.name: S.1.2.
fields.description: quality of work;

fields.name: S.1.3.
fields.description: work ethics (punctuality, wise use of time, etc.);

fields.name: S.1.4.
fields.description: creative ability and innovativeness;

fields.name: S.1.5.
fields.description: ability to handle internal and external pressures, and;

fields.name: S.1.6.
fields.description: interpersonal relations.

fields.name: I.1.
fields.description: The Institution regularly monitors and evaluates the performance of the administrative staff.

fields.name: I.2.
fields.description: The results of performance evaluation of the administrative staff are utilized:

fields.name: I.1.1.
fields.description: to improve performance and delivery of services, and;

fields.name: I.1.2.
fields.description: for promotion.

fields.name: O.1.
fields.description: The administrative personnel/staff have commendable performance.

fields.name: Master of Extension Education
fields.description: Subject for Preliminary Survey Visit (PSV)

fields.name: AREA 1- VMGO
fields.description: The Area of Vision, Mission, Goals and Objectives is the most fundamental of all the ten (10) areas to be surveyed. Everything in the Institution is justified only to the extent that it realizes its vision and mission. It is essential therefore, for the Institution to formulate the vision and mission which should be the bases of all its operations. The institution is judged by the degree to which these are attained, not in comparison with others.

fields.name: AREA 2- FACULTY
fields.description:
The standard or quality of an institution or program is greatly measured by the qualifications of its faculty. In this light, the faculty should be composed of competent members in terms of academic qualifications, experience and professional espertise. In addition, they should manifest desirable personal qualities and high level of professionalism.

To be effective, faculty members should be properly compensated and taken care of. They must be given opportunities for continuous personal and professional development. A policy of fair and equitable distribution of teaching assignments and workload should be practiced. Likewise, objective and clear promotion criteria/scheme should be adopted by the Institution.

fields.name: AREA 3- CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION
fields.description:
Curriculum and instruction occupy center stage in any educational program. These seek to research, develop and implement curriculum changes that enhance student achievement within and outside of institutions. How students learn and the best ways to educate deserve much consideration.

The quality of these two allied areas determines primarily the prestige and strength of the Institution. Areas of concern are on six parameters which encompass the following: a) curriculum and program of studies; b) instructional process, methodologies and learning opportunities; c) assessment of academic performance; d) classroom management; e) graduation requirements; and f) administrative support for effective instruction.

fields.name: AREA 4- SUPPORT TO STUDENTS
fields.description: Students are the raison d' etre for the establishment of learning institutions. This, the school has the responsibility to support the family and other social institutions in the development of the total personality of the student. Towards this end, a program of student services is designed as an integral part of the institutional effectiveness. All activities should be well planned and implemented to assist the student to attain his/her maximum potential and become a worthy contributor in his/her social environment. Student support and services complement the Academic Program.

fields.name: AREA 5- RESEARCH
fields.description:
Research is an avenue through which new knowledge is discovered, applied or verified and through which appropriate technologies are generated. Thus, it is a basic requirement for an educational institution to have a firmly established research and development program. Its thrusts and priorities should be congruent with those identified in the development plans of regional and national R and D-oriented agencies such as NEDA, DOST, CHED, etc.

The institutional leadership in research should be proactive and development in orientation. It must provide adequate and sustained budget allocation annually for the Academic Unit. Adequate physical facilities, laboratory equipment and supplies for research should be provided. The Academic Unit has to maintain strong research linkages with various R and D agencies locally and internationally.

fields.name: AREA 6- EXTENSION AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT
fields.description:
The extension function makes the Institution's presence felt in the community. It involves the application of existing and new knowledge and technology and those generated in the Institution to improve the quality of life of the people. Through the extension program, people are empowered with appropriate knowledge, attitudes and skills. Thus, extension services cater various aspects of the community life, e.g., economic growth, promotion of health, environmental management, and social transformation.

The Institution plans and implements an extension program that is need- and client-based. This program should have a budgetary support and other resource allocation. The faculty members may serve as experts, consultants, organizers, facilitators, coordinators, service providers, and change agents in the community as forms of extension and community involvement.

Careful planning and coordination with other community outreach agencies should be considered to avoid duplication of services offered to the clientelle.

fields.name: AREA 7- LIBRARY
fields.description:
The library is the heart of any learning institution. It is a synergy of people, hardware and software whose purpose is to assist clients in using knowledge and technology to transform and improve their lives.

Information and knowledge are essential to the attainment of institutional goals. The ways in which they are selected, acquired, stored, accessed and distributed within the institution will, in large measure, determine the success of teaching, research and other academic endeavors. The Institution thrives on the clear policies concerning access to, and provision of information. Thus, the library must take an active role in the development and implementation of these policies.

Each institution has a unique vision, mission, goals and objectives. These are influenced by its philosophy, geographical location and social responsibility. Similarly, as a subsystem of the Institution, the library has a unique role to perform.

fields.name: AREA 8- PHYSICAL PLANT AND FACILITIES
fields.description: The quality and adequacy of the physical plant and facilities of a learning institution determine to a large measure the successful implementation of its curricular programs. In a broad sense, physical plant and facilities include school campus, buildings and other physical infrastructures, equipment and services that complement institutional and program effectiveness.

fields.name: AREA 9- LABORATORIES
fields.description: Laboratories are included in the support systems for any academic program. Broadly defined, they cover science laboratories, speech laboratories, demonstration farms, shops, and other facilities for practicum activities essential to the successful implementation of curricular programs inclusive of their use and functions.

fields.name: AREA 10- ADMINISTRATION
fields.description: The administration is the engine of the Institution in the attainment of its vision, mission, goals and objectives. It is concerned with the general affairs of the Institution and its organizational performance. Thus, the administration adopts institutional processes and ensures that said processes are satisfactorily implemented.

fields.name: PARAMETER A: STATEMENT OF VISION, MISSION, GOALS AND OBJECTIVES
S.1
fields.description: The institution has a system of determining its Vision and Mission.

fields.name: S.2
fields.description: The Vision clearly reflects what the Institution hopes to become in the future.

fields.name: S.3
fields.description: The Mission clearly reflects the Institution's legal and other statutory mandate.

fields.name: S.4
fields.description: The Goals of the Colleges/Academic Unit are consistent with the Mission of the institution.

fields.name: S.5
fields.description: The Objectives of the program have the expected outcomes in terms of competence (skills and knowledge), values and other attributes of the graduates which include the development of: a) technical skills in Graduate Education; b) research and extension capabilities; c) students' own ideas, desirable attitudes and personal discipline; d) moral character; e) critical, analytical, problem solving and other higher order thinking skills; and e) aesthetic and cultural values.

fields.name: S.5.1
fields.description: Technical skills in Graduate Education.

fields.name: S.5.2
fields.description: Research and extension capabilities.

fields.name: S.5.3
fields.description: Students' own ideas, desirable attitudes and personal discipline.

fields.name: S.5.4
fields.description: Moral Character

fields.name: S.5.5
fields.description: Critical, Analytical problem solving and other higher order thinking skills.

fields.name: S.5.6
fields.description: Aesthetic and cultural values.

fields.name: I.1
fields.description: The institution/Academic Unit conducts a review on the statement of the Vision and Mission as well as its goals and program objectives for the approval of authorities concerned.

fields.name: I.2
fields.description: The College/Academic Unit follows a system of formulating its goals and the objectives of the program.

fields.name: I.3
fields.description: The College's/Academic Unit's faculty, personnel, students and other stakeholders (cooperating agencies, linkages, alumni, industry sector and other-concerned groups) participate in the formulation, review and/or revision of the VMGO.

fields.name: O.1
fields.description: The VMGO are crafted and duly approved by the BOR/BOT.

fields.name: S.1
fields.description: The VMGO are available on bulleting boards, in catalogs/manuals and in other forms of communication media.

fields.name: I.1
fields.description: A system of dissemination and acceptability of the VMGO is enforced.

fields.name: I.2
fields.description: The administrators/faculty attend in-service seminars and training on awareness and acceptability of the: a) Vision and Mission of the Institution; b) Goals of the College/Academic Unit; and c) Objectives of the Program.

PATH: College of Arts and Sciences > AACCUP > MSAM > AREA I: VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES | DESCRIPTION: The area of Vision, Mission, Goals, and Objectives is the most fundamental of all the ten (10) areas to be surveyed. Everything in the Institution is justified only to the extent that it realizes its vision and mission. It is essential therefore for the Institution to formulate the vision and mission which should be the bases of all its operations. The Institution should be judged by the degree to which these are attained, not in comparison with the others. | GROUP: Areas

PATH: College of Arts and Sciences > AACCUP > MSAM > AREA I: VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES > PARAMETER A: STATEMENT OF VISION, MISSION, GOALS, and OBJECTIVES | UPDATES =>  | DESCRIPTION: The Vision is the state the Institution hopes to become in the future. The MGO represents the hierarchy of aims of the institution. The Mission reflects the mandate /aim of the whole state university or state college. The Goals are the aims at the hierarchical structure below the institutional level  (the academic Unit/Institute/School); and the Objectives are the aims at the program level, i.e., what the program hopes to achieve.

The Institution shall define its mission in accordance with its legal and educational development mandate and the thrusts of the government.

The program outcomes are the foci of program accreditation. These are the competencies (knowledge and skills), values, and other attributes, which the Institution hopes their graduates shall acquire to enable them to compete for employment, locally and internationally.
